title.rendered: Men of Wisdom, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Da 1:17 To these four young men God gave knowledge and understanding of all kinds of literature and learning. And Daniel could understand visions and dreams of all kinds. Da 1:18 At the end of the time set by the king to bring them in, the chief official presented them to Nebuchadnezzar. Da 1:19 The king talked with them, and he found none equal to Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah; so they entered the king’s service. Da 1:20 In every matter of wisdom and understanding about which the king questioned them, he found them ten times better than all the magicians and enchanters in his whole kingdom. Daniel 1:17 – 20

Previously we looked at the true desire that Daniel and his friends had in their hearts and how they manifested that desire in their request to eat vegetables instead of indulging in the King’s meat. Though in the ungodly land of Babylon, they refused to be infested by it influence. Instead the Lord Himself was their influence, which was evident as He placed within them the knowledge, and skill, in all learning and wisdom and Daniel had understanding in all visions and dreams. God equipped these men to be the best of the best, the cream of the crop. Proverbs 9:10 shows us why this was so as it reads, “The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom and knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.”

These men certainly displayed this, once again in their prior actions of their food choice. Only these four would manifest the wisdom and knowledge that was matchless in light of the spiritual advisory board of Nebuchadnezzar full of astrologers, soothsayers, and sorcerers. The ungodly would not stand up to the godly. King Nebuchadnezzar summed the four Hebrews into his chambers and communed with them finding them to be ten times better then all the magicians and astrologers that were in his realm. Because these faithful Hebrews communed with the King of Kings and had the fear of the Lord in their lives, directing their motives, thoughts, and actions, they could not help but to out shine all the others. God showed that His chosen ones were truly the best of the best. As a follower of Christ, I believe that God’s people should shine as the best of the best in this ungodly world (our Babylon). We should shine as the best parents, spouses, educators, businessmen, musicians, actors, artists, writers, journalists, and leaders of our class. By class I mean as the four Hebrews boys were the best among their group and so should we be the best among ours. And what is the reason we should be the best, but to bring glory to God.

Mt 5:14 “You are the light of the world. A city on a hill cannot be hidden. 15 Neither do people light a lamp and put it under a bowl. Instead they put it on its stand, and it gives light to everyone in the house. 16 In the same way, let your light shine before men, that they may see your good deeds and praise your Father in heaven.”>

We need to covet the fear of the Lord in our lives, in order to have the same spirit manifest that shown in the lives of our four Hebrew examples. They lived in a land against their will, but thrived with that environment anyway. Perhaps you have chosen your path or perhaps it seems you found yourself in it, or it was chosen for you against your will. Whatever your scenario may be, be one that cultivates the fear of God in your life, and live in the fear and therefore wisdom of the Lord.

Application: What kind of parent, spouse, employee, teacher, etc…are you? Are you the best of the best?

Thanks

Evans

title.rendered: A time of Refreshing….Meet me at the well by Monique Anderson

content.rendered:
Good morning,

This was shared by one of our devotion team members a few years back. Be blessed as you read, Ev.

Scripture reference..John 4:7-12. We all know the story of the Woman at the well, or as the Bible refers to her as the Woman of Samaria. We have to understand the historical racial hatred and tensions between the Jews and the Samaritans (IIKings 17:21-41, Ezra 4).

Traditionally, Jewish men did not speak in public to women, even their own wives. Women were not publicly taught the law. A women’s place in society was not one remotely close to our own, but Jesus never treated women in the expected ways of his culture. He talked with them and taught them, He expected and trusted them to be able to proclaim the good news.

Lets get to know this woman. Twice this woman is called the “Samaritan Woman” or in other words a “woman of Samaria” John 4:7&9. Twice she is labeled, Twice her nationality and her religion were emphasized. This woman much like alot of us was not a “well-to-do woman”, Women of influence and affluence did not draw water from wells in thos times.

Then there is the hint of a disreputable life -“You have had five husbands and the one you have now is not your husband.” (John 4:18).

John 4:4 says that Jesus “had to go through Samaria. Jews normally avoided contact with their Samaritan neighbors by traveling other and longer routes/ What so compelled Jesus that he had to travel through Samaria? It looks to me like he intentionally sought this woman out, seeing she did not seek him. Jesus made a point on occasions to confront and single out people who had great needs, the woman with the issue of blood, Jairus, the ruler of the synagogue, whose daughter was deathly ill…etc. Was there a special need or pain in this woman’s life, is there one in yours?

I have heard various preachers and teachers talk about the Samaritan woman’s morality. But, Somehow, I much prefer to identify this woman as a sinner. It gives me hope. Hope that God would meet me where I am at, seek me out, his lost sheep and restore me and fulfill what ever need I have. To identify this woman as a sinner is not to dent her pain, for most of the sinners I know, or have met including myself were in pain of some kind. Whether or not from sinning or being sinned against there was pain.

Jesus not only spoke to this woman and initiated a conversation but he asked her for a drink of water. He very deliberately chose to affirm life instead of hide bound tradition that said this woman was not only immoral but ritually unclean. I had to look at myself and ask myself, in what ways do I insist on honoring tradition thus neglecting to bring life to others.

John 4:13-15. In these verses Jesus explains to the woman about the differences in the waters of the well and the living water. Stating that “Whosoever shall drink of this (well) water shall thirst again. But whosoever drinketh of the water that I shall give him shall never thirst; but the water that I shall give him shall be in him, a well of water springing up into ever lasting life? The woman said unto him, Sir give me this water that I thirst not”.

The well represents Jesus, and the water represents what ever need I may have if you are not saved, it first represents the Holy Spirit. All I need in is Him. In Him I move, I live and have my being. The woman brought her empty jar to the well to be filled. She also brought her empty self, little suspecting that she too would be filled that day.

Jesus is inviting us to meet him at the well…..What brings you to the well?

title.rendered: Prove Before Executing

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Romans 12:2, “And do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind, that you may prove what is that good and acceptable and perfect will of God”

Anything that we do most of the time does not just affect one day but it affects the days to come. The reason we need to be careful about what we plant in our lives ’cause sooner or later, we will look back and see why it was good or bad to plant some things. Let me share briefly on three things I call CCD. These are CHOICES, CHANGES and DECISIONS. We are what we are because of the choices, changes and decisions we make.

According to thesaurus, Choices are options, alternatives, selection, preference and pick. We can see that choices are not one thing or one plan, they are many things that give you and I a chance to pick from. Choosing is preferring one thing or a person to another. This is my theory, choices tend to start from the beginning where you choose what direction to take. The choices you and I make today will have the ability to affect our tomorrow. People choose based on the surrounding, situation, peers, the present and even more. Everyone has to make some type of choices in their lives, choosing who to marry, what kind of job you desire, what kind of house you want to live in etc

Change is to alter, modify, vary, transform, revolutionize, adjust or amend. No one can say that they have no ability to change. There are two types of changes, the change that occurs in a person and the change a person can makes. “Change” is as vital as “choice” only that “change” allows you to improve a “choice” made. The change can be big or small but everyone can see it’s significance. Changing your community begins with changed inside out to put aside what you don’t normally do and begin to develop a mindset of desiring to do it anyway, making it better. The change is not suppose to make it worse but better. Couples ought to change inside to make their marriages better and then using their change inside to change, perfect, revolutionize their marriage. Anyone who is not desiring to change is not ready for progress.

Last but not least, “Decisions”. Decisions sound like choices and it is, but I look at choice as the beginning before anything happens while decisions are made in the middle of something and now a mind has to be made up. Decisions is making judgment, assessing the situation and making a resolution to it.

All these three have one thing in common, they improve. Paul writes to the Romans and he is giving them guidelines to help them exercise these three things. One, “Do not be conformed to this world”, meaning do not try and copy the life style of this world to effectively bring these three to life because the world has set it’s standard on how to view them. Second, “But be transformed by the renewing of your mind”, Choices, changes and decisions are not made on emotions as many do, they are based on clear minds. It’s easy to do things without thinking and it affects us in the long run, but when our minds are renewed, they become in tune with our hearts, and with that we are ready to progress. “That you may prove what is that good and acceptable”, the three has to be approved, for example, when the manufacturers make any thing, they are not quick to bring it to the market, they prove it, test it, asses it to make sure it works well. They do not just look at what it can do today, they look at how long it will last, can it be effective, will it serve the purpose and so is with Christians, we have to prove what is that good, but by whose standards? men’s or God’s? God’s standards are acceptable because it’s based on His perfect will.

We can make Choices, Changes and Decisions based on what is proved to be good and acceptable and perfect will of God. What choices are you making today?, what changes have you purposed to make? what decisions do you have to make? Have you proved them to know that they are good and acceptable and are in line with His perfect will? Prove Before Executing>

Thanks

Evans

title.rendered: The Saddest Day in Heaven, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

1Co 3:12 If any man builds on this foundation using gold, silver, costly stones, wood, hay or straw, 1Co 3:13 his work will be shown for what it is, because the Day will bring it to light. It will be revealed with fire, and the fire will test the quality of each man’s work. 1Co 3:14 If what he has built survives, he will receive his reward. 1Co 3:15 If it is burned up, he will suffer loss; he himself will be saved, but only as one escaping through the flames. (1 Cor 3:12 – 15)

I heard a message many years ago which focused on the saddest day in heaven that bears repeating. Although all true Christians will make it to heaven the Scriptures says that some will suffer loss; he himself being saved, but only as one escaping through the flames. What “loss” could someone suffer in heaven? What could cause any day in heaven to be a sad one for any believer? Paul is imploring us to live our lives with the end in mind in 1 Corinthians 3:12-15 as he shares the following thoughts:

1. What are you made of? Notice that there are three materials mentioned which are cheap and temporal and there are three which are costly and eternal. Which are you made of? Does your life material, your character represent what anyone can find while taking a walk in the woods or what is rare, precious, and costly?

2. There is a testing Day coming. Most people hate pop quizzes. Paul reminds us that the testing day of what we are truly made of is coming, and it should not be a surprise to us on that Day. While non-believers will be judged in righteousness, Christians will be judged on their works unto the Lord. Are you ready for such a Day? Paul reminds us of the urgency of being ready for this test on God’s calendar.

3. The Fire Will Reveal All! What is the result when one burns up wood, hay, and straw? Ashes. However, what happens when gold, silver and precious stones are burned up? The dross (the impurities) surface until all that remains is the pure precious metal. It was the valuable metals and precious stones (Rev 21:18-21) that were used to adorn ancient temples. Are not we too the temple of God (1 Cor. 2:12)? The fire is not testing the quantity built rather the quality of what you are made of, and the fire won’t lie, but will reveal!

4. Giving a worthy Gift to Christ. What do you desire to lie down at the feet of your Lord and Savior, ashes or precious metals? We only have this one life to live. This is why Christ Himself commands “But store up for yourselves treasures in heaven…For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.” Will your face be shining in the precious metals you lay at Christ’s feet, or will your face be saddened in the ashes of temporal works? I believe many will be saddened knowing that they could have stored up the gifts He desired. Examine what you are made of; remember the Day is coming when the fire will reveal all. Give Him a worthy gift, one that He sees not only your reflection in, but more importantly His reflection!

Until the nets are filled…Blessings, Pastor Phil <><

title.rendered: Actively Waiting, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Due to unforeseen circumstances, I have not been able to deliver devotions for the last three days, my apologies. Bare with me as I battle through 4th quarter. Do keep me in prayers as at times what I do can be very overwhelming and that I will still find away to deliver the word. Ev

“Therefore my beloved brethren, be steadfast, unmovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord, forasmuch as you know that your labor is not in vain in the Lord.” (1 Corinthians 15:58)

In 1938 Orson Wells showed America the great power of the media with his “War of the Worlds” broadcast. His announcement convinced multitudes that Aliens from Mars were attacking New York and New Jersey. His compelling broadcast had scores of people shaken. Harlem in NYC was one of those places that were severely shaken. “The parlor churches in the Negro district, congregations of the smaller sects meeting on the ground floors of brownstone houses, took the “news” in stride as less faithful parishioners rushed in with it, seeking spiritual consolation. Evening services became “end of the world” prayer meetings in some (New York Times, Oct. 31, 1938.” (http://members.aol.com/jeff1070/wotw.html) The Apostle Paul in 1 Corinthians 15:58 writes too of what perhaps sounds like a “War of the Worlds” type broadcast as he describes the rapture (the snatching up quickly) of the church at the sound of the trumpet. However God’s Word is not a science fiction broadcast but a true account of what happened “In the beginning,” and what will take place in the future. Therefore, as we, The Church wait for this Great Day, Paul doesn’t instruct us to run around like lunatics with a big sign reading “The end is near” while we scream “Repent while you still have time.” Paul rather gives sound down to earth applicable instruction of what the Body of Christ is to do as it waits for the return of Christ. He writes, “Therefore” hence because this is going to take place, “my beloved brethren” those that I love listen to me. Then he touches on three characteristics for believers to have in place as they actively wait for Christ’s return as they are as follows:

1. Be steadfast. The Christian life is not a sprint but a marathon, as Solomon reminds us “The race is not to the swift… (Eccl. 9:11)” As believers we need to embrace and exhibit a stick-to-itiveness spirit, an attitude of perseverance. The word quit should not be in the vocabulary of a Christian as it pertains to following the Lord. Paul said “However, I consider my life worth nothing to me, if only I may finish the race and complete the task the Lord Jesus has given me.” Run the race and refuse to give up. When the going gets tough, and your spiritual leg muscles are weary wait on the Lord to renew your strength (Isa. 40:31)” and “…be strong the grace that is in Christ Jesus (2 Tim 2:1).”

2. [Be] Unmovable. Be stable. This world is a very unstable place that can’t ever seem to make up its mind. The Christian although living in the world is not of the world and therefore needs to show the world stability in Christ in their midst of the instability of this present world controlled by the god of this world (the devil).

3. [Be] Always abounding in the work of the Lord. What do you do for the Lord? Are you a Sunday Morning Christian only? Most Christians don’t have the work of the Lord in their schedules because much of their work is for themselves or others. Paul employs that we abound in God’s Work. Whose work are you abounding in? Are you as efficient for God as you are for your employer? When you exhibit these godly characteristics you do it for the service of the King and therefore “your labor is not in vain in the Lord” as you are spurred to serve the Lover of your soul.

Until the nets are filled…Blessings, Pastor Phil <><

title.rendered: A Picture Worth Living, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“This is what the LORD Almighty says: “Once again men and women of ripe old age will sit in the streets of Jerusalem, each with cane in hand because of his age. The city streets will be filled with boys and girls playing there.” This is what the LORD Almighty says: “It may seem marvelous to the remnant of this people at that time, but will it seem marvelous to me?” declares the LORD Almighty.”

Zechariah 8:4-5.

When reading this verse what comes to mind? Perhaps for many may reminisce about your own childhood. As a child, I remember a neighbor sitting out on his deck often with his wife. I also recall playing on one particular dead end street where I formed many childhood friendships. It was great because there were only two houses on the street so traffic was not an issue. The sight of the aged sitting outside and children playing paints a vivid picture of tranquility and safety. Many seniors today are placed in nursing homes, and many children are not playing in the streets but are, as we say in New York City, “running the streets.” When will this picture become a reality? In the hit movie, The Lord of the Rings, the King returned to take his throne, and peace reigned in the land. When our King Jesus returns the picture painted by Zechariah will be an authentic one. When Christ returns, the prophet tells us.

1. Wisdom is visible

The aged will sit in the streets, each with cane in hand. Proverbs 16:31 tells us, “Gray hair is a crown of splendor; it is attained by a righteous life.” Many today are too busy to listen to the wisdom of the aged righteous. However at Christ’s return, I believe, there will be seniors sharing their wisdom to ears ready to listen. When the aged speak do you listen to their wisdom?

2. Fun is visible

Children were depicted playing in the streets. Many of the streets nowadays are not as safe to play in. Kids are “running the streets,” getting into trouble, instead of playing. As children many of us laugh, play, dream, and have fun, but as adults we seem to let those things fade into the background, and fall by the wayside by the voice of “responsibility” and work, to which many follow its tune. Work and responsibilities never seem to end, but its time to laugh again, dream again, and yes even to play again. The old saying goes, “All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.” Keep the fun flowing in your life. When Christ returns kids will once again be able to play again and perhaps we will all be able to “be a kid again”

ourselves.

3. Enjoyment is visible

With the aged sitting in the streets and children playing in the streets, life has peace, prosperity, and security. The prophet Isaiah shares similarly in 65:20 “Never again will there be in it an infant who lives but a few days, or an old man who does not live out his years…” Praise the Lord, for this time that we have to look forward to of unhindered enjoyment with our Savior, and fellow believers. However there are plenty of things in our lives to enjoy now as we wait.

During this Christmas season my nephew Antonio and I got to spend a few quality days together. We played together, laughed together, and even wrestled around in some Star Wars light saber battles. My five year old nephew “Tones” as we call him taught me a lot of things that I forget at times, and inspired this message. As we wait for our Savior, let us appropriate wisdom, fun, and enjoyment into our Christian lives, because in His presence is fullness of JOY!

Until the nets are filled…
Blessings,
Pastor Phil <><

title.rendered: SOULFUL RELATIONSHIP, by Rev. Ronald McFadden

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Someone shared this with me, I would like to share it with you. Be blessed. Ev

If you’re not married yet, share this with a friend. If you are married, share it with your spouse or other married couples and reflect on it.

An African proverb states, “Before you get married, keep both eyes open, and after you marry, close one eye.”

Before you get involved and make a commitment to someone, don’t let lust, desperation, immaturity, ignorance, pressure from others or a low self-esteem, make you blind to warning signs. Keep your eyes open, and don’t fool yourself that you can change someone or that what you see as faults aren’t really important.

Once you decide ! to commit to someone, over time his or her flaws, vulnerabilities, pet peeves, and differences will become more obvious. If you love your mate and want the relationship to grow and evolve, you’ve got to learn to close one eye and not let every little thing bother you. You and your mate have many different expectations, emotional needs, values, dreams, weaknesses, and strengths. You are two unique individual children of God who have decided to share a life together.

Neither of you are perfect, but are you perfect for each other? Do you bring out the best in each other?

Do you compliment and compromise with each other, or do you compete, compare, and control? What do you bring to the relationship? Do you bring past relationships, past hurt, past mistrust, past pain? You can’t take someone to the altar to alter him or her. You can’t make someone love you or make someone stay.

If you develop self-esteem, spiritual discernment, and “a life”, you won’t find yourself making someone else responsible for your happiness or responsible for your pain.

Manipulation, control, jealousy, neediness, and selfishness are not the ingredients of a thriving, healthy, loving and lasting relationship! Seeking status, sex, wealth, and security are the wrong reasons to be in a relationship. What keeps a relationship strong?

Communication, intimacy, trust, a sense of humor, sharing household tasks, some getaway time without business or children and daily exchanges (a meal, shared activity, a hug, a call, a touch, a note).

Leave a nice message on the voicemail or send a nice email.

Sharing common goals and interests. Growth is important. Grow together, not away from each other, giving each other space to grow without feeling insecure. Allow your mate to have outside interest. You can’t always be together. Give each other a sense of belonging and assurances of commitment. Don’t try to control one another. Learn each other’s family situation. Respect his or her parents regardless.

Don’t put pressure on each other for material goods. Remember for richer or for poorer. If these qualities are missing, the relationship will erode as resentment, withdrawal, abuse, neglect, dishonesty, and pain replace the passion.

The difference between ‘United’ and ‘Untied’ is where you put the i.

Thanks

Evans

title.rendered: A Study On Acts 15, by David Jackson

content.rendered:
Good morning,

This message is forwarded by Pastor Phil, be blessed.

The Lord Jesus gave the great commission to His apostles. The apostles were empowered with the fruit and the gifts of the Holy Spirit of God to fulfill the commission. They understood the commission to be the crowning philosophy given and was most likely to result from believers adhering to the other teachings given by Jesus. By the time readers get to Acts 15, readers have also witnessed wonderful and spectacular things that occurred under the superintendence of the Holy Spirit. Because the lives of the apostles represented an amazing similitude of the life of the Lord, the Spirit was able to bring about the plans and purposes of God in every nation on earth. Through the great commission, believers not only demonstrate their obedience to Christ, but they also join God by and through their efforts in deposing and eclipsing the decay initiated and promoted through sin and the works of the devil. No one can read the Acts narratives without clearly and convincingly observing this.

When looking to Acts 15, world evangelism and missions were experiencing unparalleled success. Every device of the devil to curtail the momentum and the scope of the commission had been absolutely defeated. The devil could not by his outward strength oppose the strength mightily demonstrated by the unleashing of the Spirit through the lives of the apostles who were daily surrendering their lives to Him and closely adhering to the truths of Christ. The outward works were evidence of the inward surrender- and clearly, hell at its best had been undone! Amen?

Until… Acts 15.

Here, a dispute between the Greek and Hebrew ethnicities came to light.

The issue involved the proper distribution of wealth and resources. One ethnicity had been clearly overlooked and was disproportionately disadvantaged. This issue was so serious that the humble disciples- now mighty apostles had to come off the front lines of the battlefield. They left the missions and returned home to settle the dispute. The internal strife touched the very heart of the life of the church- body of Christ.

The apostles understood that if they failed at properly settling this dispute, they would show that they did not truly know the mind and heart of Christ concerning people, and the blessing of the Spirit would no longer continue with them.

The apostles properly assessed the issue. The problem was that men of similar spiritual substance were not at the head of the project. The people were instructed to elect people with whom they were acquainted and could positively ascertain the depth of their commitment and submission to the things of God. Once these people were appointed to the task, the apostles were able to resume their commission. I find, arguably, that their wisdom and success in this instance further solidified and vindicated the claims of Christ, which continued the blessing of the Spirit so much so that it was observed in Acts 17 that the entire world was turned upside down!

title.rendered: Right Temperature Incubated it, Part 5

content.rendered:
Good morning,Genesis 33:4, “But Esau ran to meet him, and embraced him, and fell on his neck and kissed him, and they wept”

Genesis 33:3, “Then he (Jacob) crossed over before them and bowed himself to the ground seven times, until he came near to his brother”. Humility will cause you to put your pride a side and say whatever it takes to deal with the offenses. In my life I don’t bow if I’m not humbled, I don’t laugh if it’s not funny and I don’t scratch where it’s not itching, something has to happen inside that causes you and I to do what we couldn’t do in the past because we have encountered with the Lord who humbled us. Seven is a number of completion or perfection, it’s known to be the number of God to which I could interpret that Jacob is coming in the name of the Lord of perfection. Genesis 33:4, “But Esau ran to meet him, and embraced him, and fell on his neck and kissed him, and they wept”. Here comes Jacob ready to face his brother not knowing how, he is expecting the worse from the one he offended. Instead of justice, he is shown mercy. Esau reaches out and embraces him. He embraced him, a sign of breaking the barrier and he fell on his neck and kissed him as a sign of love and they wept together a sign of how they missed each other. Offenses caused took away many years of their lives they could have spent building, supporting, learning, loving each other.

Who in the family have you disconnected from because of the offenses, how about friends and the church?. I believe in restoration and I know God will restore but you have to be willing, James 5:16, “Confess your faults one to another, pray for one another that you may be healed…”. Offenses will bring in you sickness that the only way to be healed will be by confessing your faults one to another, releasing people by saying I forgive you. The bible says, “Forgive us of our trespasses as we forgive”, God forgives us as we are in the process of forgiving.

Jacob for the first time saw Esau differently and so did Esau, right temperature incubated forgiveness and mercy in both of them because Jacob had encountered with God, he was able to see his brother through the eyes of God. He tells Esau in Genesis 33:10, “…I have seen your face as though I have seen the face of God”. This line has just blown my mind in the sense that the way Esau treated him that day was the same way God dealt with him when he messed up. Watch this, some people will only see the face of God in you by how you approach and deal with the offenses. I pray that we God will install in each of us a thermostat that controls what comes out of us and He will build something in us that will cause us to propel love, mercy, forgiveness, repentance, joy, peace that we may deal with the offenses in away pleasing to God. May He sit on what the enemy wants to incubate.

title.rendered: Medication for Moral Decay, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Before today’s message, I have been asked to share a gospel message tomorrow at a friend’s wedding, may I ask you to keep me in prayers for boldness, powerful message and that people’s hearts will be open to the gospel and convicted. Enjoy Pastor Phil’s message. Ev

“If my people, which are called by my name, shall humble themselves, and pray, and seek my face, and turn from their wicked ways; then will I hear from heaven, and will forgive their sin, and will heal their land.” (2 Chronicles 7:14)

Can you imagine what the Garden of Eden must have been like? Before sin entered into the world, all things were perfect. However, when we look at our land now, it can easily be seen how sin has left its ugly stain. In America there are 95% to 97% that profess to believe in God. Despite this belief abortion continues to rise, homosexuality and fornication increases, death and destruction appear to have no end in sight as the moral decay of the nation continues to spiral downward. What is God’s remedy to the problem of moral decay in a nation? It is not through politicians, it is not through new programs, manipulative speeches, education, or financial growth. God points out they He is looking to His people to repent! Why do God’s people need to repent?

There is a lack of humility. “Shall humble themselves” Many of God’s people do not read His word, nor submit to it. God is calling for His people to humble themselves. Why because God resists the proud but gives grace to the humble. If we don’t humble ourselves God will do it for us! Remember Jonah running away from his evangelistic responsibility, God humbled him. Will you humble yourself? God’s promise for those that humble themselves is that he will lift you up. In God’s economy God will resist the proud hearted and welcome the humble hearted. Perhaps that is why the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom.

There is a lack of pray “Humble themselves and pray” When God’s people don’t pray, what they are saying is that they don’t need God. One normally doesn’t talk to people one does not know, and the reverse is true. Recently a professing believer shared that he did not see the efficacy of prayer. Jesus prayed and He was the Son of God, the Apostles prayed and they walked with the Master, what is your excuse if you have a prayer less life?

There is a lack of seeking God. “seek my face” I’ve heard it well said that many seek the hand of God but Jesus sought God’s face. Jesus sought His Father many early mornings, when everyone was sleeping, he was seeking. Mark writes, “Very early in the morning, while it was still dark, Jesus got up, left the house and went off to a solitary place.” Jesus spoke with His Father. I picture that Jesus not only prayed, He listened to his Father’s voice, early in the morning, late at night, and sometimes all night he sought the Father. Like a thirsty traveler crawling through a desert seeking water, Jesus went alone to a solitary place. When one seeks God, one seeks His face, and upon seeing His face one seeks His will. Seeking God will result in seeking to do His will.

There is a lack of seeking the lost “and turn from their wicked ways” What could be a more heinous crime for God’s people then to fail to warn the unsaved about Judgment Day and the horrors of Hell and then watch them go to Hell? Most of the church has taken a vow of silence and do not speak to lost people about the things of eternity, the truth of Jesus Christ. We must turn from our wicked ways.

There is a Condition. then will I hear from heaven, and will forgive their sin, and will heal their land.” There are two types of promises, once that is unconditional, and the other that is conditional. The IF…THEN…is the conditional one, which God speaks at the end of the above verse. If we humble ourselves, pray, seek His face, and turn from our wicked ways, then God will bestow forgiveness and healing upon our land. If we don’t do it, God will not grant forgiveness and healing.

Until the nets are filled…

Blessings,
Pastor Phil <><

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Genesis 33:4, “But Esau ran to meet him, and embraced him, and fell on his neck and kissed him, and they wept”

Genesis 32:24, “Then Jacob was left alone; and a Man wrestled with him until the breaking of day”. In wrestling there is winning and loosing, and here Jacob is wrestling with a Man who we know is God. The flesh and the Sprit wrestling each other. His flesh wanted to be control as he always did but where God was sending, only His was going to be in control. Another thing I see from him wrestling with God, Jacob encountered with a power he could not manipulate and he would not let go. Genesis 32:26, “…I will not let you go unless You bless me”. Remember that the first time he tricked his brother and took away his birthright, then took a way his blessing, in Laban’s home, he mixed animals to get the best but when he encounters with God, he cannot manipulate Him. Here is my thinking; he might have said in his heart, “I will not let you go till You have changed me inside out.

I now understand that when I’m wrestling, there is war between the flesh and the Spirit and God is changing me then installs the thermostat to face all that I have been running from. Before God allows you to deal with the offenses, He will change you in and out but you got to be willing. Jacob realized that if God wasn’t going to help him, he couldn’t face his brother and his future was going to be in jeopardy too. He humbled himself, he prayed, he wrestled with God in readiness to meet his brother. Had God not worked on Joseph first, maybe meeting his brothers could have turned into revenge. When God works on us, we can face everything we’ve been running from. His right temperature of love and mercy will propel us to incubate the same to the people who have hurt us.

Genesis 33:1, “Now Jacob lifted his eyes and looked, and there was Esau coming and with him were four hundred men… vs. And he put the maid servants and their children in front, Leah and her children behind, and Rachel and Joseph last”. Remember how Jacob wrestled with God and could not let Him go until He blessed him and so Jacob reports this in Genesis 32:30, “So Jacob called the name of the place Penile, “For I have seen God face to face, and my life is reserved”. There is something about seeing God face to face that causes us to change. Live with God longer and your life will be transformed, 1John 3:2, “Beloved now are we the sons of God and it does not yet appear what we shall be, but we know that when He shall appear, we shall be like Him for we shall see Him as He is”. The word “know” is an absolute statement and then the word says we shall see Him as He is and when we do, we shall be changed. The more you encounter with God the more you become like Him and the more you can deal with offenses differently. Jacob gets changed inside out and ready to meets his brother. The chapter I just mentioned when starting this paragraph troubled a bit. Jacob has been sending messengers to meet with his brother on his behalf, then comes a time that to meet him, he looks a head and there is Esau coming with four hundred men who look like warriors. He takes the maidservants and puts them in front followed by Leah and her children and finally Rachel and Joseph. Why in that order? The ones he cares for the most he puts them behind and the ones he cares for the least he puts them in front so that incase anything happens, Esau can kill them in the order of less cared for. Understand something, just because you encounter with God does not make you come back crying Holy for it’s a process of becoming like Him. You can see Jacob still has issues but thank God he is not who he used to be. He is sacred but running back, I call this fighting scared. Later in the same chapter, he lies to his brother but watch his life gets transformed over and over again. Some are frustrated right now because God did not take care of everything immediately, hey if He did everything all at once, it will be too much for you to handle. Slowly by slowly He is changing you inside out and for the sake of the message, look back and see what progress you’ve made since He met you. To finish

title.rendered: Resting in the Midst of Trouble, By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“Peter was therefore kept in prison, but constant prayer was offered to God for him by the church. And when Herod was about to bring him out, that night Peter was sleeping, bound with two chains between two soldiers; and the guards before the door were keeping the prison.”(Acts 12:5 -6)

Times of adversity have a way of testing our faith. What do you do when adversity strikes? Do you run away, pray, complain, and become depressed? The gospel message that is preached by many at this time is this, “God has a wonderful plan for your life.”Is this the Gospel that Jesus preached? I don’t see this in the Scriptures. Jesus said in John 16:33 I have told you these things, so that in me you may have peace. In this world you will have trouble. But take heart! I have overcome the world.”

Let me give you some background about the verse above. James (one of the Apostles) was just beheaded. Herod saw this pleased the Jews so he locked Peter up in prison to do the same thing to Peter that he did to James, take his head off with a sword. Peter is sitting in prison, basically as far as he is concerned, on death row waiting to die. He doesn’t stay up all night worrying; he is not even trying to escape. What would you be doing at this point? Do you think that you would be doing what Peter was doing, SLEEPING?!?! This is truly faith in action. How can Peter sleep during a time that his life is about to be taken?

1. Peter leaned faith from the Master. When the disciples were in the boat during the storm they were frantic, but Jesus was at rest sleeping. They woke up Jesus and said ‘Lord, save us! We’re going to drown!” He replied, “You of little faith, why are you so afraid?” Peter was no doubt experiencing this lesson which, unbeknown to him, he would need to apply while waiting to die in a prison cell. Who has shown you how to respond by faith during trouble?

2. Peter applied the faith he learned. Peter was sleeping like a parishioner in the back row of a church. Peter’s faith was resting in Christ, because faith snoozes even in a storm. Stephen had already been stoned, and James beheaded, yet Peter slept in the cell, as Christ slept in the boat. Paul admonishes us to, “Be anxious for nothing…”Do you rest during times of trouble, or do you doubt, complain, worry, etc…?

3. Peter’s faith surpassed understanding. I wonder what the guards that he was chained to, were thinking as Peter slept. I can imagine that Peter fell asleep first and then because Peter was being an inactive prisoner they fell asleep after him. Perhaps they said to each other, “how can this guy sleep when he is going to be headless tomorrow.”This is speculation of course. Peter was a man of prayer, and the church was also praying for him, which caused the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, to guard his heart and mind through Christ Jesus.”

Do you experience this kind of peace amidst your trials? Do others see the peace of Christ in you during the storms of your life? Do you share your faith with others so they as they repent and put their faith in Christ they too will know how to rest in the midst of trouble. The unsaved are currently in the biggest trouble ever, awaiting Hell if they die without the Savior? What are you doing about it?

Until the nets are filled…Blessings, Pastor Phil <<

Thanks

Evans

I believe in my heart that God is bringing restoration in the land, in the families, in marriages, in schools, in the jobs etc. What God is doing is a process and we as His people should be ready at any given moment of time to move when He says move. Jacob was living a foreign land and God decides to move him come back home, a place he had ran a way from. I am understanding that God wants to restore first the relationships that were broken before He can elevate. Is this not the same way God dealt with us, when we failed the test and no sacrifice could pave a way for us to relate to Him, then Jesus come down from heaven, wrapped Himself up in the flesh, died on the cross and paved a way for us to have that relationship that we lost when Adam sinned in the garden of Eden. Every other blessing is an after fact. Jacob is scared of going back to deal with the past and so is someone from our devotion team. It is crucial for God to restore broken relationships because where He wants to take us, we cannot bring baggage that will wear us out. Jacob recognized that God walked with Abraham (his grand father) and Isaac (his father) and God had promised to walk with Him back. Watch this, a part from the blessings he had in form of wives, children and possessions, He had a promise from God that everything will be fine. He did not know what the end result would be but all had was promise. We too have the same promise, Jesus said, “lo I am with you always”

Genesis 32:11, “Deliver me, I pray, from the hand of my brother; from the hand of Esau; for I fear, lest he come and attack me and the mother with the children”. Do you see that for the offenses to be broken there has to be humility, a broken heart understanding that we’ve all failed. In as much as we needed mercy from God when we failed, someone needs our mercy when they fail us and we need their mercy when we fail them. Jacob is humble and calls first calls on God, then he realizes that if he is going to face the past, God has to help him deal with it. Something funny is that Jacob is trusting in God but at the same time he is also making plans on how to appease his brother. He has his plans and God has His own plans. He plans to give Esau presents to help compensate for what he did but just like God, He does not need sacrifices prepared by man, listen to what David says in Psalm 51:16&17, “For thou desirest not sacrifice; else would I give it; thou delightest not in burnt offering. vs. 17, the sacrifices of God are broken spirit: a broken and a contrite heart”. Presents will not buy the way out, broken heart and a contrite spirit will. God is about to transform Jacob in a mighty way that as he is praying and waiting on God to move, he has nothing to do but try and come up with something that he thinks might work. If it’s not of God, it will not work!!

If God is going to restore you, He has a lot of clean up to do in your life?. God does not want Jacob again to meet his brother and deal with things in the flesh like before and I know why. Already in the past he had messed up because his temperature had no thermostat and no one to control it. On the other hand, God is doing the same in the life of Esau who is not mentioned very much about his dealing with God but later we will see that God installed a thermostat in Him too and was controlling His destiny. God controls what we can handle through Him the reason we ought to thank God for installing a thermostat in us and controls it. To continue

Good morning,

Genesis 33:4, “But Esau ran to meet him, and embraced him, and fell on his neck and kissed him, and they wept”

We laid a ground work getting to understand the lives of two brothers. We defined who they are, their character and understanding that we too are from the same source but are different. Last night on TV they were talking about the famous murderers and I was thinking of how I’m no better than them because the bible says in Romans 3:23 “ALL HAVE SINNED AND FALL SHORT OF THE GLORY OF GOD”, Jeremiah 17:9, “THE HEART IS DECEITFUL ABOVE ALL THINGS AND DESPERATELY WICKED. No wonder the bible says, “Romans 3:10, As it is written: ” There is none righteous (good), no, not one”, this humbles me.

From my experience I have noticed that harbored things in the heart tend to surface and directed towards someone not so much because of who they are, but because of what they do.. As long as Abel had not won the attention of God through his sacrifice, Cain was okay but the moment Abel did that which was right before God, Cain had a problem with it. I saw this with Joseph and his brothers and so was the prodigal son and his older brother. Many are fuming with frustrations because they were not treated right or were ignored. People get offended so many times and mark this, offenses build fences. We need to understand that offenses will come cause we are living in a fallen world, Jesus knew of this and so He told us and the disciples in advance, Luke 17:1, “Then he said unto the disciples, it is impossible but that offenses will come”. Offenses is one of those junk in us and if boiled correctly, and gets incubated at the right temperature, be sure it will come out unless the Lord who controls the temperature has His hands on the thermostat. Esau is offended and you can see that he is angry, bitter, has hatred towards his brother and we see these things boiling inside ready to explode and the next move is that he is destined to kill his brother. How many do the same, they may not literally want to kill physically but they kill spiritually. Many have killed with the words because of the anger and hatred that was within. I usually say that if you really want to know someone, watch and see how they deal with frustrations, anger, bitterness, these things leave people to be disoriented unless the Lord is in control. I have met people who have disconnected themselves from their brothers and sisters because of the offenses, children who have disconnected themselves from their parents because of the offenses. People who have walked away from the church because of offenses, the bible says that offenses will come. Be ready for them at any time, and remember that you will not be the only one offended, people around you will and so will you also offend someone else. Constantly people look at what has been done to them and not what they have done to someone else. Offenses caused Esau and Jacob to be disconnected for a long time. Two boys who could have grown up together could not because a few episodes.

I believe with all my heart that the enemy uses the offenses to bring divisions everywhere. Instead of us concentrating on fighting the enemy, we take on each other leaving the real enemy. Give the devil an inch, he will take the whole ruler and beat you with it!!.(as pastor Phil would say) . It is important to know your enemy. 2Corithians 10:3, “Though we walk in the flesh, we do not war after the flesh, vs. 5 casting down imaginations and every high thing that exalt itself against the knowledge of God, and bringing every thought into captivity to the obedience of Christ”. People are flesh and blood and they are not the enemy, the enemy is what is inside that the devil is trying to boil at a right temperature to incubate it. Know who your enemy is otherwise you are bound to fight the wrong one. From my view I have come to understand that offenses most of the time are my own imaginations and my bible says cast them down. Offenses will take one’s mind from doing the right thing, bring every thought into captivity and under the obedience of Christ.

Can’t stress enough, offenses will come, how we deal with them matter’s a lot. You can run from them but you will not be settled until you deal with them. Jacob ran to his uncles place but one day he had to come back and deal with it. I believe that God will not do greater things until He has restored. God did not really use Jacob greatly until He restored both Esau and Jacob by making them meet and reconcile. What has caused you to disconnect from father, mother, brothers, sisters, church, friends etc, get the enemy off the thermometer and let the Lord take control. To continue

title.rendered: An Offering Worth Offering 4, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“Therefore, I urge you, brothers, in view of God’s mercy, to offer your bodies as living sacrifices, holy and pleasing to God-this is your spiritual act of worship.” (Rom 12:1)

The ultimate offering is when Jesus Christ sacrificed His life on the cross to pay the penalty for our sin(s). 1 Peter 3:18 reads “For Christ also has once suffered for sins, the just for the unjust, that he might bring us to God, being put to death in the flesh, but quickened by the Spirit:” Galatians 3:13 reads, “Christ has redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us: for it is written, Cursed is every one that hangs on a tree.” There is no sacrificial offering like the sacrifice of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. If Christ did not die in our place we would forever be stained and saturated in our sin and transgression.

Paul’s urging is for you and I to offer ourselves as an offering completely to the Lord and his service. Before a priest in Israel could minister on behalf of others, he was obliged to present himself in a consecrated condition and the sacrifices he offered were to be without blemish (Mal 1:8-13). The priest offered God a dead sacrifice, while we are called to be a living sacrifice. A living sacrifice can crawl off the altar of obedience. Again Samuel wrote, To obey is better than sacrifice, and to heed is better than the fat of rams” (1 Sam 15:22). We are to offer our lives, our whole lives to the Lord as an offering to Him. What else can we really offer to the One that founded the entire world? Let me close with this illustration.

I recall a true story of a nine year old boy who lived in a rural town in Tennessee. His house was in a poor area of the community. A local church had a bus ministry that came knocking on his door one Saturday afternoon. The kid came to answer the door and greeted the bus pastor. The bus pastor asked the little boy if he and his parents ever went to church. The boy replied no. The bus pastor shared his faith with the young boy whose heart melted at the gospel story. The boy then went to church with the bus pastor. While at the church the little boy just sat there, clue-less of what was going on. A few minutes into the service these tall unhappy guys walked down to the front and picked up some wooden plates. One of the men prayed and the kid with utter fascination watched them walk up and down the aisles. He still didn’t know what was going on.

All of a sudden like a bolt of lightning it hit the kid what was taking place. These people must be giving money to Jesus. He then reflected on the free gift of life he had received just twenty-four hours earlier. He immediately searched his pockets, front and back, and couldn’t find a thing to give Jesus. By this time the offering plate was being passed down his aisle with a broken heart he just grabbed the plate and held on to it. He finally let go and watched it pass on down the aisle.

He turned around to see it passed down the aisle behind him. And then his eyes remained glued on the plate as it was passed back and forth, back and forth all the way to the rear of the sanctuary. Then he had an idea. This little nine year old boy, in front of God and everybody, got up out of his seat. He walked about eight rows back, grabbed the usher by the coat and asked to hold the plate one more time. Then he did the most astounding thing I have ever heard of. He took the plate, put it on the carpeted church floor and stepped into the center of it. As he stood there, he lifted his little head up and said, “Jesus, I don’t have anything to give you today, but just me. I give you me!”

We are to become the offering unto the Lord through our obedience. When you offer yourself fully to the Lord in your time (the way you spend your time), talents (the manner that you use the gifts God bestowed upon you), and treasures (your finances and material blessings), you become the living sacrifice that God desires of you. How are you spending you time; does your schedule reflect His Lordship? How do you use your talents for Him, the ones that He has given you? Does your check book, credit card statement, and spending, reflect that Jesus Christ is Lord of you? May you be an offering worth offering unto the One you call Lord.

Until the nets are filled…

Blessings,

Pastor Phil <><

Genesis 33:4, “But Esau ran to meet him, and embraced him, and fell on his neck and kissed him, and they wept”

There is a cause for everything, when you look at the end result, you can trace back it’s origin. For creation, we can trace back to know there is a creator God, for the things made, you can trace them back to the manufacturer. I think that things don’t just happen, this is my opinion!!!!. Today when you are sick and you go to the doctor, what happens, they begin to ask you about your family history. “Did your grandma have kidney problems or heart disease?” or whatever the doctors will ask you. This tries to help them trace the origin. Every tree has the roots and the roots determine how strong the tree can be and how much it can produce. Shallow roots will cause the tree not to be resistant to heavy winds and water that washes the tree away. Once again, every problem has it’s roots and in as much as we can try and fix the branches and the fruits, dealing with the root will open doors for healing and restoration.

Esau and Jacob have one of the most powerful stories in the bible and one of the most disturbing stories too. We know that these two are twins, whether identical or not I don’t know but all I know is that they are twins. Esau is older than Jacob and in as much as during that time women could have as many children as they could, Rebekah only gave Isaac two sons. From my experience, twins tend to get a long very well maybe up to a certain stage in their lives. Even identical twins have some things in their lives that make them unique and the bible takes the time to define each boy’s uniqueness. Esau is a hunter and Jacob appears to be the mama’s boy, Esau is well built and hairy, Jacob is smooth and skinny, Esau is tough and careless and Jacob is cunning and manipulative. Two boys, twins but are different in things pertaining life. We too came from the same source but very different. Some things we were never born with but for some unknown reasons we have them. Certain things no one taught us but they are in our system. No one can really go back and say that on such and such a day, I took a course in lying or stealing. No one can say that they graduated with a degree in anger and frustrations at a given time. Therefore how come we have so many things we were never born with? In the fallen world we live in, already we failed the test the first day we took the class and that is the day we were born. Every junk that you could ever think about was already in each of us and some of the things were waiting for the right time to be incubated before we saw the results. Some of them did not manifest because there was no such great temperatures to incubate it.

We are all glad that some things did not incubate in our lives to bring the worse out of us. When we understand our own limitations and realize that everyone around us is as bad as we are, we begin to look at things differently. Just because someone’s hidden things came out at a certain time does not mean that it’s not in us. We are just glad that God prevented them from showing up. I thank God for the blood, not only did the blood take care of what I did, but it also took care of what I could have done and what I could have been. I know many thank God for cleansing them of the past sins but think about it, do you know who you could have turned out to be if the blood did not also take care of what you could have done? I don’t want to even imagine what my end result could have been if God did not show up in my life.

To get back to Esau and Jacob there is something about Genesis 27. Isaac was old and almost dying, he has a chance to bless one of his sons and the right candidate becomes the first born as it was in the olden days. Isaac gives his son Esau instructions as what to do before being blessed. Rebekah hears all the instructions and wants to help her little boy Jacob get the blessing instead of Esau. Remember that every thing that you could think about is in both boys, one is about to be incubated at a very high temperature. Esau is busy in the field trying to please his father on the other hand his brother is out to steal his opportunity of being blessed.  Plan is well orchestrated in the absence of Esau and it does not come to his mind that there is something being planned behind his back that has to be done real quick before his return.

This is ground work for message. Today’s introduction will lead us to talk about anger, bitterness, distress, offences and even resentments, some of the major killers even in the church today. Understanding ourselves better will help us deal with issues that has brought divisions, have torn families and churches apart.

title.rendered: An Offering Worth Offering 3, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,“But the king (David) replied to Araunah, “No, I insist on paying you for it. I will not sacrifice to the LORD my God burnt offerings that cost me nothing.” 2 Samuel 24:24

Most people enjoy getting something for free.  Recently my students asked me why everything can’t be for free.  I responded by saying everything costs somebody something.  Araunah the Jebusite attempted to give David a free offering so that David would have an offering to give to the Lord.  David responded by saying, “No, I insist on paying you for it. I will not sacrifice to the LORD my God burnt offerings that cost me nothing So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen and paid fifty shekels of silver for them.

The Spirit Filled Life Bible points out “The threshing floor of Araunah was on Mount Moriah where Abraham offered Isaac (Gen. 22:2).  Abraham was told by God “Take your son , your only son, Isaac, whom you love, and go to the region of Moriah… Sacrifice him there as a burnt offering.”  Abraham offered that which was precious to him, his son.  However, before Abraham brought down the knife upon his son, “the angel of the Lord called to him out of the heavens and said, ‘Abraham, Abraham…lay not a hand upon the lad…now I know that you fear God seeing you did not withhold your son, your only son from me.”

How could David stand on the same plot of land that Abraham stood upon and not bring a costly offering.  Abraham was asked by God to offer his son as an act of obedience to God.  The Prophet Samuel said, Does the LORD delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices as much as in obeying the voice of the LORD?  To obey is better than sacrifice, and to heed is better than the fat of rams” (1 Sam 15:22).  When David brought the offering to the Lord there was a plague in
Israel.  2 Samuel 24:25 states, “David built an altar to the LORD there and sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. Then the LORD answered prayer in behalf of the land, and the plague on Israel was stopped.”  David’s focus was upon the healing of others.

Had you ever had a Garden of Gethsemane experience?  It was in a garden where Adam first said, “Not your will but mine be done,” and it was in a garden where Jesus fell to His knees and prayed, “Not my will but Yours be done.”  At the time, His disciples were asleep; so when it comes to being obedient to God, and sharing the gospel of truth with the unsaved, don’t be discouraged.  Simply get on your knees and pray Father, I desire to be obedient to you, and the thought of sharing my faith with others makes me sweat great drops of blood in fear.  Yet not my will, but Yours be done (Ray Comfort).”  God is still looking for those that would give an offering worth offering, an obedient life to Him.  Obedience is challenging, but if you’re like me, at the times that I don’t obey the Lord, it only makes things worse off.  There are so many people that are dying without Christ, because so many Christians are not being obedient to share their faith.  The late Bill Bright in his book, The Coming Revival, wrote that only 2 percent of Christians regularly share their faith with others.

Are you being obedient to the voice of the Lord in your life?  Are you sharing your faith with others?

Until the nets are filled…

Blessings, Pastor Phil <><

title.rendered: An Offering Worth Offering 2, by pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

My apologies, could not deliver devotions as I was traveling. Pastor Phil continues with his series, be blessed.

“In the course of time Cain brought some of the fruits of the soil as an offering to the LORD. But Abel brought fat portions from some of the firstborn of his flock. The LORD looked with favor on Abel and his offering, but on Cain and his offering he did not look with favor.” (Genesis 4:3 – 5)

In part one, we saw that an offering worth offering to God is one that is accurate (hits his heart) and one that is authentic (given out of our love of putting Him first).

God respects when we bring the best of what we have to offer. Cain was a farmer that “brought some of the fruits of the soil as an offering to the Lord.” He brought an offering to God was it was not the best; it was second hand, leftovers. God supplied the seed, the hydration, and the sunlight to grow the fruit. God supplied the best environment that was needed to grow the fruit. Abel brought the best to the Lord. Abel was an animal keeper, most likely a shepherd that “brought fat portions from some of the firstborn of his flock.” God supplied the initial animals, because unknown to Evolutionists, “the chicken did come before the egg.” God also supplied the food, water, etc… that the animals needed to grow and be healthy. I picture Abel looking at his sheep and thinking which one would God be pleased with to receive as an offering. Abel chose the top of the flock, and offered them to the Lord.

God respects when we bring our offering by faith. Heb 11:4 gives further insight about these two brothers as it read, “By faith Abel offered God a better sacrifice than Cain did. By faith he was commended as a righteous man, when God spoke well of his offerings. And by faith he still speaks, even though he is dead.” If Abel gave God his best, then how would Abel breed more healthy sheep? Abel seemed to apply wisdom in not letting his left hand know what his right hand was doing. When Abel gave his best sheep, he saw his best leaving and not being replaced immediately. Abel gave by faith, not by sight. God supplies all our needs, and I believe that as God respected Abel’s offering, God supplied a healthy vibrant flock for him. Jesus said, “For whoever wants to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for me will find it.” In the same regards in God’s economy when we lose it (give it unto the Lord) we gain. When we try to keep it (holding back from the Lord) we lose. This was not so with Cain, who seemed to keep the best and give God the second best.

God accepts offerings from those that belong to Him. Jesus spoke about false coverts (people that think that they are saved when they are not). Jesus told many parables about this including the parable of the sower, the foolish virgins (false) and the wise virgins (genuine), the good fish (genuine) and bad fish (false), the wheat (genuine) and tares (false), the sheep (genuine) and the goats (false). It seems that Cain foreshadowed the false while Abel foreshadowed the genuine. God accepted Abel’s offering, but rejected Cain’s. A father probably wouldn’t hang another child’s drawing on his refrigerator? However, he would proudly display his own child’s drawing on it? Cain’s heart did not submit to God’s heart, even though he approached God and gave God an offering. God accepted the offering from Abel as Abel’s heart did submit to God’s heart. A son wants to please his father, and does whatever is necessary to “win” his dads approval. Perhaps we can liken Cain and Abel to Judas (false) and Peter (genuine). Both were called to lay down their lives for Jesus, but only one did. Are you bringing God your best as an offering by faith because you genuinely belong to Him? Are you bringing an offering worth offering? To be continued…

Until the nets are filled…

Blessings,
Pastor Phil <><

title.rendered: An Offering Worth Offering, Part 1, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“In the course of time Cain brought some of the fruits of the soil as an offering to the LORD. But Abel brought fat portions from some of the firstborn of his flock. The LORD looked with favor on Abel and his offering, but on Cain and his offering he did not look with favor.” (Genesis 4:3 – 5)

Back when I was in Bible College God taught me a very humbling lesson. I was serving on the homeless outreach team that brought food, blankets, and clothing to the homeless on the streets of Philadelphia. It was winter time and there was a thin layer of snow on the ground. This night I was speaking to a man that asked if I had a pair of gloves for him. I looked proudly at my brand new warm leather gloves that I was wearing and thought there is no way that I am giving my gloves to this man. I looked down and saw a glove frozen into the snow. I picked it up, dusted it off and offered it to the man. With disappointment he turned and walked away from me.

Later that evening while in my dorm room God severely convicted me of my pride and greed. God reminded me that I wore the gloves that He provided for me. The glove I offered to the cold man, God did not respect. I blew it bad because of my pride. I believe that something of this sort happened to Cain when he offered his offering to God in Genesis four.

Cain and Abel both approached God, both brought an offering to God, both offerings were examined by God, but only one was respected by God. What made Abel’s offering please the Lord? The writer of Hebrews gives us further insight. Heb 11:4 reads, “By faith Abel offered God a better sacrifice than Cain did. By faith he was commended as a righteous man, when God spoke well of his offerings. And by faith he still speaks, even though he is dead.

God respects an accurate offering “The LORD looked with favor on Abel and his offering” One must hit the bulls-eye when it comes to pleasing God. One can’t just throw anything God’s way an expect Him to honor it. In this case the bulls-eye is the heart of God. Abel hit God in the heart with his offering. Abel seemed to know what God would desire to receive from that which he blessed Abel with. Cain was angry with God, but did not offer an accurate offering. He wanted God to accept whatever he threw toward God. What has God blessed you with? Many unfortunately chock on their blessings, rather then bless the Lord with that which He has given. God’s heart is about his glory and blessing others. How accurate of offering are you bringing to God? Is it connecting to His heart?

God respects an authentic offering “The LORD looked with favor on Abel and his offering.” God looked with favor upon Abel. Abel desired to give God his very best. I believe Abel loved God with all his heart, mind, soul and strength. Abel was genuine toward God, he put God first. Abel placed God’s glory before his own, because Abel was authentic. Cain’s offering was not out of his love for God, he did not put God first. God didn’t look with favor on Cain nor his offering. I believe Cain’s offering was not genuine in the sense that it was given as though it were Cain’s best, but God knew otherwise. Perhaps this is one of the reasons after Cain killed his brother that God said to Cain, “If you do what is right, will you not be accepted? But if you do not do what is right, sin is crouching at your door; it desires to have you, but you must master it.” One can’t bring an offering with an unrighteous heart before God. Are you authentic with God in your offering, or phony like Cain? To be continued…

Until the nets are filled…

Blessings,

Pastor Phil <><

title.rendered: Reasoning With God

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Isaiah 1:18, “Come now let us reason together”, says the Lord, “Though your sins are like scarlet, They shall be as white as snow; though they are red like crimson, They shall be as wool”.

This is a message I shared back in 03, be blessed

I would like to share a principal that has helped me many times, reasoning with God. Different people have different view and conviction over reasoning with God. It’s like whatever the Lord says is final. I have always refused to pray, “Lord, whatever you choose to do, do it” and my simple reasons are, God has given me a chance to call on Him and ask Him. He says you don’t get because you don’t ask. Ask and it shall be given unto you, seek and you shall find, knock and the door shall be opened unto you. It may sound like being arrogant but this is His word, in His book and all I am doing is exercising it. MY ASKING, SEEKING AND KNOCKING IS LOOKING TO HIM TO ACT ON IT ACCORDING TO HIS WILL. My prayer is that, “Thy will be done on the matter I have presented to you” and His will could be yes, no, wait.

When it comes to reasoning with God, it’s kind of tough to deal with it. Could it be a sign of disobedience or a sign that we don’t recognize who He is and His position? He has said, “come now and let us reason together”, can you see that this His idea and not ours?. When I am coming to reason, I am aware of who He is and His position and all I am doing is humbling myself under His mighty hand. Just to bring something in mind real quick, have you ever questioned God or asked God a question? The two may look and sound the same but they are very different. Questioning would mean interrogating God with a lot of why and what questions. Asking God question I could say trying to find out what to learn from what you are experiencing. I wish I had some deeper meaning of the difference but this is how I look at it. There is something that is interesting about God that I don’t know how to explain it, when the bible says, “And the Lord remembered so and so”. Does it mean God had forgotten him or her? How about making something that will remind God of the covenant He made? Does this mean that there are times God forgets? You know what, He is God, He can choose to remember or forget and as for our sins, when we confess, He chooses to forget every bit of it.

Moses reasoned with God when God was on the verge of wiping out the children of Israel in the desert. He says, (paraphrase), “What would the Egyptians think? They will say that you brought the Israelites out of the land of Egypt to kill them in the desert” and also “That You were not God enough to bring them to their destiny”. Hezekiah also received a message from prophet Isaiah (I believe) that it was time for him to get his house in order for he was going to die. What did he do, he did not just say, “well that is what the Lord has chosen for me and I choose to go by it”, no, he did not even send Isaiah back to God, He went to God himself to reason with Him. All he could talk to God about was the word, “remember”. God had brought him from far, many things he suffered, he was just beginning to enjoy the blessings of the Lord, he did not feel ready to die yet. Abraham reasoned with God when God was out to destroy Sodom and Gomorrah, Abraham approached God to reason with him and this is what he said (paraphrased), “Will you wipe the righteous people living in the Sodom?”, Suppose there are 50 righteous people, will you destroy Sodom? and the Lord said, “If there are 50 righteous people, I will spare the city”. This happened until the number dropped to about five if I remember well. Gideon reasoned with God and so was Elijah and many more.

All these people had one thing ion common, their reasoning was inform of intercession which means standing in the gap and pleading with God. Reasoning with God over your loved ones, yourself, your situation, your ministry, His calling in your life. This is not trying to twist the arm of God to do whatever you want, this is allowing God to see the situation in the way that you see it and He in turn acting on it according to His will. Abraham reasoned with God but there were no enough people to spare Sodom so He took Lot out of Sodom and destroyed the city. Suppose Abraham had not reasoned with God, maybe Lot and his family would have perished. If Moses did not reason with God, maybe God would have destroyed the Israelites. “Come now let us reason together says the Lord”.

Isaiah 1:18, “… “Though your sins are like scarlet, They shall be as white as snow; though they are red like crimson, They shall be as wool”. One of the verses I believe in Psalms David reasons with God by saying, “If you hold on to my transgressions, who will stand?”. As we come to reason, regardless of how our sins may look or sound, He will wash us as snow and though they may be red, soiled and stained, they shall be as wool that as we reason, we reason with pure hearts. I love to plead and reason with God for it has many times done me well. We were once alienated and now adopted to call God Abba Father. We are heirs joint heirs with the Father, He has put us in positions we would never imagine or think and He has called us to reason with Him, have a conversation, plead with Him. Like I said, this is a principal that has worked for me and you may not see it as I do but I had to share this with someone. He has called me to reason with Him!

Thanks

Evans
