title.rendered: There Is A Guide, Part 3

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Genesis 24:1-66, “…you will not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I dwell; but you shall go to my country and to my family, and take wife for my son Isaac”

Abraham’s servant was guided not to take a woman from Canaan for Isaac but to go back to Abraham’s home, family to find a wife for Isaac. Abraham had a vertical relationship with God and with that He could come boldly trust God for what was best for his son.

 Genesis 24:12, “Then he said, “O Lord God of my master Abraham, please give me success this day and show me kindness to my master Abraham’s vs. 13, “Behold I stand by the well of water, and the daughters of the men of the city are coming out to draw water, vs. 14, Now let it be that the young woman to whom I say, “Please let down your pitcher that I may drink” and she says, “drink, and I will also give your camel a drink, let her be the one You have appointed for Your servant Isaac”. What an interesting portion of scripture for a vertical relationship with the Lord will cause you to pray for a person whom you can have an horizontal relationship with. Abraham’s servant was not sure of what was good and acceptable for his master’s son and so once again, he is guided to pray specifically. I know people are used to praying Lord whatever you want to do, do it and that is good but at the same time the Lord has given us the liberty to ask of Him according to His will. When I have a vertical relationship with the Lord, He reveals to me what His plans are and those become my desires and now I ask according to His will that He may execute it in my life. Mathew 7:7, “Ask, and it shall be given unto you:….” vs. 8, “for everyone that asketh receiveth…” and this does not mean I can just walk into the kingdom and ask for anything I want, no, I have connection with Him to know what I can ask that in turn  He may give. The bible says that we don’t get because we don’t ask and many don’t get because they ask a miss meaning not according to His will. Because the servant was guided, he asked for a specific woman a virtuous woman and his prayer was not selfish, it was a prayer that everyone would want to pray for a companion. Mark 11:24, “What thingsoever you desire when you pray, believe that you receive them and you shall have them”. I don’t see the reason why I cannot come to God, pray specifically for something and allow Him to act on it according to His will?. Peter did it when he said, “If it’s You Lord, command me to come to You on water”. He was specific on what he wanted to do and how he wanted to do it as long as the Lord approved and the Lord said  ” come ” , that was approval to the desires of his heart. I saw this with David many times and I choose to be specific with the Lord.

 Something I love about this servant is the fact that as he was praying, specific, calm, relaxed, seating down not trying to find himself what he went to look for. I believe that when you have prayed, you patiently wait for the Lord to intervene as to whether what He wants to do will just appear or He will give you divine direction to lead you as to where to go. In this case, he needed to be still and know that God was in control of the situation and God knew who he needed and the Lord made her come to the well at the right time. God in due time will fix things His way without you standing on his way, His timing is always perfect

 Genesis 24:14, “… And by this I will know that You have shown me kindness to my master”,  In vs. 15 before he finished praying, Rebekkah appears, a very beautiful woman, a woman of good heart and determination. She is a woman of character, a virtuous woman who fears God, a woman who is walking in the ways pleasing unto God. She has a vertical relationship first even before thinking of a horizontal one. She is out doing her normal business and here she meets a servant and she is kind to him and amazing thing, she does everything the servant prayed to God about.  I have a feeling that God had laid in the servant’s heart exactly what to pray for, He had already provided even before she was revealed to the servant. God knows even before you pray and when you come to Him, you may approach an issue differently but the more you pray, the more He will guide you to pray for it His way and not your way. Could it be possible that the servant could be the type of the Holy Spirit praying on our behalf? Romans 8:26, “Likewise the Spirit helps our infirmities for we know not what we should pray for as we ought: but the Sprit itself maketh intercession for us with groanings that cannot be uttered”. The Holy Spirit is our guide. To continue

 Thanks

title.rendered: There Is A Guide, Part 2

content.rendered:
Good morning,

 Genesis 24:1-66, “…you will not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I dwell; but you shall go to my country and to my family, and take wife for my son Isaac”

 Abraham ‘ s days on earth had been numbered, God had blessed him beyond measure even with a son in his old age for inheritance. He had one more thing to do before passing into eternity and that was to find his son a wife. He called his servant to explain to him what he requires of him and he makes a vow to follow his master’s order. Genesis 24:3, “…you will not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I dwell”. I asked the Lord, what does this mean? Abraham is living in Canaan, a land that flows with milk and honey and yet he does not want his son to marry a woman from Canaan? It’s very simple, Abraham’s people and family served the Lord while the Canaanites did not. This applies to us today that the world represents Canaan yet we live in it and the instructions from the Lord, don’t find someone and have a relationship with who is in the world meaning who is not saved, who is not walking with the Lord for they have no vertical relationship.

 When horizontal relationship is not defined by the vertical one, it tends to make things complicated by that I mean, for example, if you marry someone who is not saved, when you have kids, by whose standards and life style will they be brought up the saved or unsaved? See anything the Lord tells us is for our own benefit and in as much as we might try and do it in another way, it will not work. It’s very easy to be attracted and want to have a relationship with someone who is not saved and may even think of it as an evangelistic date but most of the time it doesn’t work out. 2Corinthians 6:14, “Do not be unequally yoked with the unbelievers: for what fellowship has righteousness with lawlessness? A believer lives under grace and keeps the law in mind but the unbeliever could care less for he or she has no standards to live by and so what is right for you may not be right for them and what is wrong for you may not necessarily be wrong for them why? because you have a vertical relationship they don’t have. Someone said, “Be busy serving the Lord and moving forward and while in that process, you will look on your side one day and you will see someone busy serving the Lord. The neat thing, both of you will be heading towards the same direction”. Those who have no vertical relationship will have no reason to walk towards the same direction in which you are going. But when both parties who would like to be in a relationship have both vertical relationship, they can cultivate a good horizontal relationship.

 Genesis 24:4, “but you shall go to my country and to my family and take a wife for my son Isaac”, Not only is the servant told what not to do, he has been given another instruction which is a good one as to where to find someone for Abraham’s son,  ” go back to my people ” . What does this mean to us, go back to my people called by my name, people who serve me, look up to me, who have been washed, whose sins have been covered. I’m glad to know that in our churches today there are many young people who have a vertical relationship with the Father and the Father is willing to help them develop horizontal relationship in due time. This is what I call a crucified life for vertical and horizontal presents the cross reflected in Galatians 2:20, “For I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I but Christ liveth in me, and now the life which I now I live in the flesh I live by faith of the Son of God, who gave Himself for me”. Christ is the definition of love and so what He has presented to me through a vertical relationship, I can do the same horizontally.

 For those who have prayed for a mate and a times felt you were denied or did not qualify or it was taking too long, just know, the blessing may be delayed but not denied. The blessing is ready, you are being prepared for it. I ‘ m a witness to this, there is a guide. to continue.

 Thanks
 Evans

title.rendered: Launch Out Into The Deep

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Luke 5:1-11, “…Master we have toiled all night and caught nothing; nevertheless at Your Word, I will let down the net”

Peter and his friends are professional fishermen. This may have been their occupation all their life. They knew fish seasons and where to fish so they are experts. On this particular night, they are out fishing as always only to catch nothing all night long. Morning comes and the men are disappointed and all they can do is wash their nets. What a night!!!!!, many at the market are waiting for the fish, they need to make money, they need to feed their families.  I can imagine them pondering over what they will tell the people. In simple, their normal, daily routine had been interrupted, brought to a halt. Have you ever be at a place where everything you knew how to do at your job or at home all of a sudden was interrupted and those looking up to you were disappointed in you? Hang on, help is on the way.

Romans 8:28, “And we know that all things work together for good….” Jesus shows up in the situation teaching the word of God. He has great multitude listening to Him teach. Great thing about Him, He comes right when there is a need. In as much as people need a touch from Him, every one has a different need and my need may not be yours. He sees a boat and desires to use it maybe as a pulpit to preach. Peter is asked to move the boat closer to the shore and he is faithful to do it though disappointed by the previous night. Jesus wants to do something big and so He prepares everyone by teaching them, It is not mentioned to us as to what He was teaching on I will guess “faith”. Peter must have been listening carefully for the bible says in Rom 10:17, “… faith comes by hearing and hearing by the word of the Lord”. After Jesus did the Kingdom’s work, He tells Peter to launch into the deep, meaning cast his nets again in the same place he had tried fishing last night. Listen to his response “Master we have toiled all night and caught nothing; nevertheless at Your Word, I will let down the net”. It’s easier to hear the word, try another place but to try the same place???. Yes you might have tried surviving in the same job and you already lost hope and instead of Him telling you to move on, He tells you to cast your nets again. You may have applied for a promotion and nothing has come through because of frustrations, instead of Him telling you to move out, He is telling you to cast your nets again in the same position. It’s not about what we know, what we can do or qualified to do, it’s about what God can do when we can’t do it. It’s being obedient to the word of God to the point where you do as He has said regardless of what you know. It may never make sense but the key word is ” be obedient”. After all, many things that God say don’t make sense and if you tried to make sense out of them, you will never amount to anything because while you are busy making sense out of them, your blessings will be passing you by.

Peter’s faithfulness causes him to make the biggest catch in his history of fishing. He begins to call on his friends to come out and help pull the nets which proves Pro 10:22, “The blessings of the Lord maketh rich and adds no sorrows with it”. The blessings of the Lord overtakes as the bible continues to say “try me and see if I will not open the windows of heaven and pour you out blessings that you will not have enough room to contain all of them”. What I’m I saying this morning? YOUR PLACE OF MISERY COULD BE YOUR PLACE OF BLESSINGS, but you have to have the faith and take Him at His word cause surely His word shall not return void. Had Peter explained how professional he was, and how he had done this for many years and refused just to apply the simply instruction, the blessing would have passed him by.

If God still gives you grace to be able to deal with something that you really would like to give up on, keep on standing and launching out in the deep, you have come too far to go back, you have gone too deep to fail.

* By the way, join me in praying for the peace of Jerusalem, that’s a command from the bible
Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Permitted May Not Mean Approved, Part 2

content.rendered:
Good morning,

1Samuel 8:7, “And the Lord said to Samuel, “Heed the voice of the people in all that they say to you; for they have not rejected you, but have rejected Me, that I should not reign over them

In the story about the prodigal son, we see a son who insisted on having his inheritance. Though the father did not approve of it, he permitted it because his son insisted and you know the end result.

Going back to the Israelites, God did not want them to have a king because He knew how an earthly king would be to them. He loved them, cared for them and wanted to protect them. He even went a head to show them a picture of what will happen they have a king 1Samuel 8:10, “… This will be the behavior of the king who will reign over you”, read it for yourself and you will see terrible things the king would do to them if they insisted on having one. Amazing thing, even with the warning, they still refused. vs. 19, “Nevertheless the people refused to obey the voice of Samuel; and they said, “No, but we will have a king over us, vs. 20, “that we also may be like all the nations, and that our king may judge us and go out before us and fight our battles”. We have been warned some relationships will ruin our lives by killing our morale to serve the Lord, will put us in compromising situations, will lead us to wrong places, will kill the anointing in our lives yet at times we still insist that we want it. Certain jobs and positions will make us stop praying, depending on God, going to church, stunt our growth, yet we insist that we want it. According to the word of God, we have been shown what will happen if we step out of HIS WILL and because of the hardness of heart we still want to do it any way. I know many do it out of fear of being left out or rejected, but why pray then “Your kingdom come, thy will be done on earth as it is done in heaven”. PEOPLE ARE AFRAID TO LET GO OF A THEN THAT THEY MAY HAVE A NOW and it’s because they cannot believe God enough to say “Lord if I let go this, I know you can bring that” and so when we allow them into our lives, Jesus might still be the Savior of our lives but not the Lord of our lives. Whoever or whatever you have allowed in your life becomes now the king of your life and God is left out of the picture. We know of how Saul the king the Israelites cried for did when he came to power, everything they were warned of was manifested and while talking about that, how about Samson who was told not to be involved or even marry any woman from Philistine, he insisted and therefore he was permitted to marry and yet we know how he ended his life.

I’m a great listener of my earthly father’s counsel. Through his Christ like life, experience and wisdom, every big thing I want to do I pass it by him to get his wisdom and blessing, and every time he has given me a picture of the situation I had not seen. With that I have been able to make some better judgments, permitted and approved. I saw that he was like Samuel mediating between God and the Israelites. I even leant from there that what I thought I wanted may have not been necessarily what I needed. We need to surround ourselves with godly Father figures who can counsel us. I believe we can save ourselves a lot of heartaches if we listen to their counsel for the bible says, Proverbs 11:14 ,”Where there is no counsel, the people fall; But in the multitude of counselors there is safety”. If you get counsel and you insist on going the opposite, the counselor may not stop you, the road you are heading may at one point stop you. Let’s listen to wise counsel that we may make good judgments permitted and approved. It’s for our own good.

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Doing What You’ve Heard by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
“Do not merely listen to the word, and so deceive yourselves. Do what it says. 23 Anyone who listens to the word but does not do what it says is like a man who looks at his face in a mirror 24 and, after looking at himself, goes away and immediately forgets what he looks like. 25 But the man who looks intently into the perfect law that gives freedom, and continues to do this, not forgetting what he has heard, but doing it—he will be blessed in what he does.” James 1:22 – 25

Do you enjoy learning about God’s word? Isn’t it great to listen to preaching that helps you to comprehend God’s Word more clearly? There are some people that just seem to be able to break down the Word of God in such a masterful way. I have learned many things throughout my years as a Christian from others. There are particular people in my life that have helped me to learn about a particular spiritual discipline, or a certain biblical truth or principle, ect…. Why is it that there is so much learning of truth, but so little doing of truth? We learn very much, and appropriate so very little. We learn how to pray, but then do we actually pray? We learn how to study God’s Word, but then are too busy to study it. We learn how to share our faith, but then walk by thousands of people, never sharing God’s truth with those that are Hell-bound. James (the bother of Jesus) wrote that listening to God’s Word is not enough. James said about God’s Word:

1. “Do what it says.” If we only listen to God’s Word, whether listening to a preacher or listening to God Himself and we don’t do it we deceive ourselves. Do you know that failing to do God’s Word after you have heard it shows that you are deceiving yourself.

2. Don’t forget what you look like. James uses the illustration of one that stands in front of a mirror and looks at oneself, but then walks away and forgets what one looks like. Imagine if one checked oneself in the mirror and was on their way to an interview. This person had all kinds of stains on their clothing, but off to the interview he went. This person saw what he looked like in the mirror, but then seemed to forget what he looked like, because he didn’t do anything (clean his stain, or change his clothing) to make a change. Yet so many do this with God’s Word, looking into it as a mirror, seeing the change that needs to take place, and going on without making the change.

3. The blessing comes to those that are doers of His Word. James says that the one that looks into the Word of God intently (carefully, with purpose) and continues to do this, not forgetting what he has heard, but doing it – he will be blessed in what he does. Are you deceived, have you forgotten what you look like (what His Word says), or are you doing what God is speaking to you. What is God speaking to you? Write it down, and then do it. If you need help appropriating speak to a mature believer, or a spiritual leader. You can always write Evan and I for help, and we would be glad to help if we can. Christianity today has much learning, but little application. Be the type of Christian that Jesus wants you to be, one that does His Word.

Until the nets are filled…Blessing Pastor Phil

title.rendered: Doing What You’ve Heard 2 by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good Morning,

Mt 7:24 “Therefore everyone who hears these words of mine and puts them into practice is like a wise man who built his house on the rock. Mt 7:25 The rain came down, the streams rose, and the winds blew and beat against that house; yet it did not fall, because it had its foundation on the rock. Mt 7:26 But everyone who hears these words of mine and does not put them into practice is like a foolish man who built his house on sand. Mt 7:27 The rain came down, the streams rose, and the winds blew and beat against that house, and it fell with a great crash.” (Matthew 7:24 – 27)

I have a great friend named Joe Bukoweicki that built houses. If you were to ask him what the most important thing on a house is, he would tell you the foundation. A house is only as strong as the foundation that it is built upon. Jesus uses this language of foundations when he speaks in Matt 7. Jesus shares that there are two kinds of builders (people), those that have built their lives upon the solid foundation of Christ the rock, and those that have built their house upon the unstable foundation of religious sand.

Have you ever seen those incredible sculptures of sand art? Click to check it out. http://images.google.com/images?q=sand+art&ndsp=20&svnum=10&hl=en&lr=&start=60&sa=N There is so much time that goes in the aesthetics, but it can be easily destroyed because it still is only sand. There are many that build their lives upon the shifting sands of religion, and tradition. However Jesus said of those that do this, that they are foolish. The reason for there foolishness is because although they heard the Words of Jesus, not the words of a religious leader, but Christ, they refused to put them into practice. It is not hearing but doing that shows a true convert. The foolish man was the one who heard the sayings of Jesus, but did not obey them. It’s not the world that hears the sayings of Jesus and doesn’t obey them. Most know only the “Golden Rule” and “Judge not,” and even then their understanding is darkened. However, the Church is filled with false converts who sit among God’s people and hear His words, but don’t obey them. They build their house on sand rather than on the firm foundation of Jesus Christ and His words (Ray Comfort).” A. W. Tozer said, “It is my opinion that tens of thousands of people, if not millions, have been brought into some kind of religious experience by accepting Christ, and they have not been saved.”

The true convert builds his house upon the rock. “He is the Rock, his works are perfect, and all his ways are just. A faithful God who does no wrong, upright and just is he. (Deut.32:4). Paul wrote “…and that rock was Christ (1 Corinthians 10:4).” http://images.google.com/images?q=foundation+%2B+house&svnum=10&hl=en&lr=

The test will show the foundation! Jesus said that the rain will come down, the streams will rise, and the winds will blow and beat against that house (the sand house, and the rock house). The rain of tribulation, the streams of temptation, and the winds of persecution will beat against your life. If Christ is not your foundation, you will fall with a great crash; ultimately Hell will be the place you “crash” for eternity. Don’t build your house on religion, or tradition, Jesus has made this abundantly clear. If you do you are playing Russian roulette with a fully loaded gun! title.rendered: Where you see a Clark Kent God See’s a Superman by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good Morning,

“When the angel of the LORD appeared to Gideon, he said, The Lord is With You Mighty Warrior.” (Judges 6:12)
When they are little, most boys play with toy weapons and play games where they kill the bad guy and they play themselves as the hero.  My nephew loves to be called Batman, Spiderman, or the Hulk.  He often says, “Let’s fight Uncle Phil.”  But boys grow up, and some never seem to reach manhood in their identity, there are just grown up boys.

In the account the Lord saw Gideon thrashing wheat in a winepress to keep it from the Midianites.  He was hidden in a pit, as most thrashing was done in the open areas where the wind could blow away the chaff.  And as he is doing this an angel appears to Gideon and says “The Lord is with you mighty warrior.”  This hardly sounds like an applicable title for a man with such timid actions.  This is an ironic title to one hiding out; it was not as if Gideon decided to go in full faith and face the enemy.  Gideon himself even challenges the validity of the angel’s words (v.13)  “But sir,” Gideon replied, “if the LORD is with us, why has all this happened to us? Where are all his wonders that our fathers told us about when they said, `Did not the LORD bring us up out of Egypt?’ But now the LORD has abandoned us and put us into the hand of Midian.”  The Lord saw victory where Gideon saw defeat, and the Lord saw “Superman” where Gideon saw “Clark Kent – mild mannered reporter.”  I myself from a young child was drawn to the man inside the man, when it came to super hero’s.  Clark Kent would slip into a phone booth and come out as Superman, Bruce Wayne would disappear to the Bat Cave and emerge as Batman.  What boy is not drawn to this imagery, and this identity?  Because in the heart of every boy he wants to play the hero, live the adventure, fight the battle, and rescue the beauty.

The Lord saw the “Batmen,” the “Superman,” within Gideon.  He saw a mighty warrior and therefore identified him as such.  Oh how I would personally love to one day hear the words from my Lord, “Well done thy brave and faithful warrior!”  Gideon didn’t see himself as God saw him.  That sounds all too familiar, like us.  What do you see when you look in the mirror.  Many see a failure, a foul-up, a pretender, a hypocrite.  But what does God see when he looks at you? 

The LORD turned to him and said, “Go in the strength you have and save Israel out of Midian’s hand. Am I not sending you?”  Go in the strength you have, I can imagine was the furthest characteristic from Gideon’s mind.  The Lord was using identity terms such as “warrior” and “strength,” to describe Gideon, and he was probably thinking responding words like “Not me” or “Strength, you must be mistaking me for another Gideon.”

title.rendered: Is God Fair or is He Just? By: Lisette Rivera

content.rendered:
Good morning,This morning’s word will come from a friend of Pastor Phil’s, Lisette. Please thank her for this much needed message. Allow it to minister to you, and please share it with others.

Many times when “bad” things happen to “good” people, the first thing that is said about the situation is “That’s just not fair!” or “Such and Such was a good person.” But you know what? We won’t get it. It’s not our place to try and figure out God’s reasoning behind letting something “bad” happen to a “good” person.

“For My thoughts are not your thoughts, Nor are your ways My ways”, says the Lord. “For as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are My ways higher than your ways, And My thoughts than your thoughts” Isaiah 55:8-9 NJKV

I don’t know about you but the last time I checked the earth was pretty far from heaven. Since this is the case, we cannot possibly completely understand God’s thoughts. And you’ll just get a headache trying to force the issue.

Did you know that the word ‘Fair’ is never used in the Bible to describe God’s character? ‘Fair” appears only as a description for beauty. Now ‘Just” on the other hand is used over 50 times to describe God. When something is fair, it is limited by our own experiences thereby justifying the event/action. When something is just, it is justified by God’s understanding.

God’s justice may not make a lot of sense to us, but know that He makes it all work out in the end, because He has seen it all from beginning to end.

“And we know that all things work together for the good of those who love God, to those who are the called according to His purpose” Romans 8:28 NJKV

To close I would like to share a thought in light of Lisette’s wonderful message. There is no place more clear to deal with the issue of justice and fairness than looking to the cross of Calvary. If God were merely fair, was it fair to allow His sinless Son to die for sinful, undeserving people? If ever a man could say, “it’s not fair,” it would have been Jesus Christ. It wasn’t fair for Him to go to the cross for you, or for me. Yet, “While we were yet sinners Christ died for us.” It is to our benefit that He is not fair, because we would all end up in Hell, because there is no one good, no not even one Jesus said as He spoke to the rich young ruler. “Why do you call me good?” Jesus answered. “No one is good—except God alone (Mark 10:18).” This man called Jesus good, apart from calling Him God, and only God is good. In civil law, a good judge must punish crime. If he turns a blind eye to injustice, then he is corrupt and he himself should be punished. “Righteousness and justice are the foundation of Your throne; mercy and truth go before your face” (Psalm 89:14). God is rich in mercy to all that call upon him “But God, who is rich in mercy, for His great love wherewith He loved us…” (Ephesians 2:4). Eternal life is in Jesus Christ, that is why Jesus said, “”He who hears My word and believes on Him who sent Me has everlasting life, and shall not come into judgment, but has passed from death into life” (John 5:24). “If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just and will forgive us our sins and purify us from all unrighteousness (1 John 1:9).” “We know that we have come to know him if we obey his commands (1 John 2:3).”

title.rendered: Marks of a Disciple 3, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,“Then said Jesus to those Jews which believed on him, If ye continue in my word, then are ye my disciples indeed;? ?And ye shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you free.” (John 8:31 – 32)

I often hear that all one needs to do when it comes to salvation is to simply believe. Some take it a step further and use Romans 10:9 which Paul writes, “That if you confess with your mouth, “Jesus is Lord,” and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved. If one quoted this verse alone as the means of salvation, then it sounds like Paul is saying all one must do is to confess sin, believe Jesus and salvation is bestowed. However the key in this whole thing is Jesus is Lord. This confession was made publicly among other disciples. Then this new convert was disciple into Christian maturity.

When the Apostle Paul was on his way to kill Christians Christ met him on the road to Damascus and “…suddenly there shined round about him a light from heaven:? 4 ?And he fell to the earth, and heard a voice saying unto him, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?? 5 ?And he said, Who art thou, Lord? And the Lord said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest: it is hard for thee to kick against the pricks.? 6 ?And he trembling and astonished said, Lord, what wilt thou have me to do? Did Paul confess Jesus as Lord, yes. Did he believe in his heart, yes. Did he tremble with conviction of his sin, yes. Jesus confronted him with the Law, the sixth commandment, “thou shall not murder,” for that in fact was what Paul was doing to Christians. After this conversion took place Paul said to Jesus, “Lord, what wilt thou have me to do.” Paul seemed to instantly know that he must now be a doer of God’s word and not simply one that hears, believes and confesses Jesus as Lord. Now he would have to live under the Lordship of Jesus Christ from this day forward.

The problem in many churches today is that preaching takes place, the pastor has people close their eyes and repeat a prayer of confession for sin after him. Then many times the person’s life does not change, and many times the person doesn’t return to the church even for a second visit. We call this type of person a false convert, because they have made stake to claims of salvation unto Jesus, but they wanted a Savior but not Lord. However the two cannot be separated, Jesus is Savior and Lord of my life.

In light of this, in the above key Scripture verse, Jesus spoke to the Jews who had believed Him. Therefore belief in Jesus was already present. Jesus then went on to say, “If you hold to my teaching, then you are my disciples indeed.” This is called a conditional statement because it uses IF and THEN, meaning IF you do this, THEN this will be the result. However IF one does not do this, THEN one will not get the same result. Jesus said one must continue in His word. The Expositors Bible Commentary says, “Receiving his teaching would mark them as genuine disciples and would lead them into a deeper experience of truth.” This learned truth then, would liberate from legalism, superstition, and dead works of tradition which had developed over the years. Jesus felt the necessity of making perfectly clear the conditions of discipleship.

Are you reading the Scriptures daily (continuing in His Word)? Are you obeying what you reading and showing Him to be Lord over your life? If you are then you are His disciple, you know the truth and have been set free, therefore REJOICE! If not then repent quickly, today, right now, and make the change that Jesus is calling you to make. If you are lord then He is not, but if He is Lord then you are not. Choose the latter.

title.rendered: Marks of a Disciple 2, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,Our apologies for great delay in delivering the word.

“He who receives you receives me, and he who receives me receives the one who sent me. Anyone who receives a prophet because he is a prophet will receive a prophet’s reward, and anyone who receives a righteous man because he is a righteous man will receive a righteous man’s reward. 42 And if anyone gives even a cup of cold water to one of these little ones because he is my disciple, I tell you the truth, he will certainly not lose his reward.” (Matt 10:40 – 42)

In part one of Marks of a Disciple; we examined the new commandment Jesus gave to His disciples, to love one another as He has loved them. In light of that Jesus speaks again about another mark being his disciple. Jesus starts off by talking about receiving Him.

  1. Whoever receives a disciple receives Christ. Those who treat His disciples bad, treat Jesus bad. Remember when the Apostle Paul, formally called Saul, was persecuting Christians? Jesus showed up on the road to Damascus, knocked him down and said, “Saul, Saul we do you persecute Me [Jesus].” It was clear from the lips of Christ that those who come against Christ’s disciples are coming against Jesus, and those that receive His disciples, welcome Christ.
  2. Whoever receives Jesus receives God. God was the One that send Jesus as the sacrifice for sin. Many Jewish people, and others as well, want to reject Jesus but receive God. This simply can’t take place because Jesus is God. “Philip said, “Lord, show us the Father and that will be enough for us.” Jn 14:9 Jesus answered: “Don’t you know me, Philip, even after I have been among you such a long time? Anyone who has seen me has seen the Father.” Jesus also said to the Pharisees, “’I tell you the truth,’ Jesus answered, ‘before Abraham was born, I am!’ At this, they picked up stones to stone him,”
  3. Whoever gives a cup of cold water to the little ones is Christ’s disciple. Jesus is the living water that brings satisfaction to the thirsty. He said, “Everyone who drinks this water [natural physical water] will be thirsty again, 14 but whoever drinks the water I give him will never thirst, and “If anyone is thirsty, let him come to me and drink. 38 Whoever believes in me, as the Scripture has said, streams of living water will flow from within him.” In context of the prophet’s reward, and the righteous man’s rewards, there is the disciples reward here. Those that refresh Christ’s disciples will not loose their reward. Disciples of course have the living water in them, but even they need to be refreshed. The reason Jesus said that those who drink of the living water will NEVER thirst again is because the source will never run dry. Abraham’s well could run dry (John 4), but Christ’s well can never run dry, because His well has always been full to overflowing with eternal life sustaining water. Will you share that water with another disciple today and so refresh their spirit. Please pray, encourage, and minister to at least one before the day is through. As God uses you to bring His living water to others, He will make sure you too are filled. Receive His disciples, receive Christ and therefore God Himself, and give some refreshing water of refreshment to one that is thirsty today.

title.rendered: Marks of a Disciple, By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“A new commandment I give unto you, That ye love one another; as I have loved you, that ye also love one another. ?By this shall all men know that ye are my disciples, if ye have love one to another.?” (John 13:34 – 35)

How can one tell is someone is a fan of a particular sports team? Perhaps is one wears a teams clothing, jersey, hat, etc…. However if I put on a NY Yankee jersey does that mean that I am on the NY Yankees? Of course not! How then can one know if one is a disciple of Christ? Well one way to know Jesus said is that His disciples would have love one to another. This sounds very quaint, loving, caring, and mushy. Love as many have said is perhaps the most abused word in language. Jesus spoke to His disciples and gave them a new commandment, and that was to love one another as Jesus had loved them. Many feel that the love Jesus was speaking of here, is the demonstration of love that Jesus had shown them up to this point He was speaking to them. Jesus had shown them love, but He did not display His greatest act of love at the time He was instructing them to love on another. That display would be shown at the cross. Jesus would die for His twelve and for the whole world. This was the love that He was commanding them to love one another with. He said a new command, not a new idea, suggestion, or option I give you, but a new command. Jesus further said, “Greater love has no one than this, that he lay down his life for his friends.” Jesus was calling them to lay their lives down for one another. When is the reason that Jesus wanted His disciples to love one another as He had loved them?

Christ’s Love is pure. John wrote, “How great is the love the Father has lavished on us, that we should be called children of God!” God is the source of love, and He lavishes that love upon His children as a mother lavishes love upon her child. His pure love, not love as the world gives, needed to be in their hearts if they were going to be Christ-like.

  1. Christ’s Love is demonstrative. The world sits in condemnation and judgment. The world is guilty of breaking God’s Law, they love the darkness and hate the light. Jesus said that when His disciples shine their love toward one another, that the world would see it and know who Christ’s disciples are. The world can only see this kind of love if Christians step out of the four walls of the church building and live it out among all men. Many non-Christians have seen televangelists manipulate people for their money. Christ didn’t die in a church, He died in plain view of the people, in the sight of all men. Oh that we would die to ourselves that He would live in us, and we would be His feet and hands extended. I laugh when people say I love God, it’s the church I have a problem with. That is like saying I love you but I hate your husband or wife. Husbands and wives are one, and so is Christ and His body. His body must love one another, the church needs that love to flourish, and the world needs to see it as a living tangible witness.
  2. Christ’s Love is evidential evidence. Jesus said “…by this all men will know that you are my disciples….” When you live his love out loud, it shows that Jesus is real. Why would go out of your way to help, give, bless, provide, even sacrifice for another brother or sister in Christ, because Christ is real. Why would you display the fruit of the spirit, bless those who persecute you, love your enemies? Practical Christian lives points to the reality that Christ is real, and the Savior of the world. Demonstrate his pure love today as evidence that Jesus is Savior, Lord, and soon and coming King!

title.rendered: Denial Vs. Betrayal (By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
"Now when the even was come, he sat down with the twelve. And as they did eat, he said, Verily I say to you, that one of you shall betray me. And they were exceeding sorrowful, and began every one of them to say to him, Lord, is it I? (Matt. 26:20 – 22)

At the Last Supper Jesus is eating with His twelve and speaks about betrayal. This is perhaps the worst gesture that a "friend" can do to another friend, even worse then death, because one has to live with the fact that betrayal meant a complete hardening of the heart in the midst of the relationship. Jesus makes the statement that one of his "friends" there would deny him, and when He said this everyone of the disciples became sorrowful and looked introspectively saying "Lord is it I?" No one pointed fingers at Judas as if he had a big hook nose and devilish horns coming out of his head. The Scriptures point out that two of the disciples went against Jesus at His hour of need. Peter denied Jesus and Judas betrayed Jesus, so what's the difference, or are they the same?

Well let's look at Peter first. Jesus says to the group that "all you shall be offended because of me this night: for it is written, I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock shall be scattered abroad." Peter answered and said to him, "Though all men shall be offended because of you, yet will I never be offended." Jesus responded by saying to him, "…this night, before the cock crow, you shall deny me thrice." Peter said to him, "Though I should die with you, yet will I not deny you. Likewise also said all the disciples." Peter really meant to keep his word, but when he was tested he folded under pressure three times just as Jesus said. We know that later is Peter's life he got things together and became a leader among the Apostles and wrote two books of the Bible bearing his name.

Judas on the other hand turned against Jesus a bit differently. "Then one of the twelve, called Judas Iscariot, went to the chief priests, And said to them, What will you give me, and I will deliver him to you? And they covenanted with him for thirty pieces of silver. And from that time he sought opportunity to betray him." Judas was plotting and scheming behind the scenes with those that wanted to see the destruction of Christ, and the disbanding of his disciples. Those evil men used Judas as a pawn to work an inside job on Jesus. While in prayer in the Garden of Gethsemane, Judas comes with his entourage of chief priests and armed soldiers. "And forthwith he came to Jesus, and said, Hail, master; and kissed him. And Jesus said to him, Friend, wherefore are you come? Then came they, and laid hands on Jesus, and took him." Jesus calls him friend and yet Judas still sells him out in betrayal. With friends like Judas who needs enemies?

Peter grabbed his sword when they laid hold of Jesus and cut of one of the soldier's ears to defend the Lord. He was showing his seriousness of protecting Jesus at all costs, even death. After Peter's denial the Scriptures says that Peter "went out and wept bitterly [in repentance], showing himself a true convert." Judas however felt the guilt of betraying Jesus for thirty pieces of silver and tried to give it back, admitting that he had sinned against innocent blood, and he threw the coins down at the feet of the priests and went forth and hung himself. Both men felt sorrow for their sin, but Peter repented while Judas did not and committed suicide, showing himself to be a false convert.

Application: If you find your actions plotting against your relationship with Jesus, repent right away, because the Judas that lives in us tries to rise up and take charge. If you have denied Jesus by your life in anyway also repent and move on and do great things for your Lord. Remember your faith MUST stand trial, so that it can be refined.

title.rendered: The Saddest Day In Heaven (By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
1Co 3:12 If any man builds on this foundation using gold, silver, costly stones, wood, hay or straw, 1Co 3:13 his work will be shown for what it is, because the Day will bring it to light. It will be revealed with fire, and the fire will test the quality of each man's work. 1Co 3:14 If what he has built survives, he will receive his reward. 1Co 3:15 If it is burned up, he will suffer loss; he himself will be saved, but only as one escaping through the flames. (1 Cor 3:12 – 15)

I heard a message many years ago which focused on the saddest day in heaven that bears repeating. Although all true Christians will make it to heaven the Scriptures says that some will suffer loss; he himself being saved, but only as one escaping through the flames. What "loss" could someone suffer in heaven? What could cause any day in heaven to be a sad one for any believer? Paul is imploring us to live our lives with the end in mind in 1 Corinthians 3:12-15 as he shares the following thoughts:

  1. What are you made of? Notice that there are three materials mentioned which are cheap and temporal and there are three which are costly and eternal. Which are you made of? Does your life material, your character represent what anyone can find while taking a walk in the woods or what is rare, precious, and costly?
  2. There is a testing Day coming. Most people hate pop quizzes. Paul reminds us that the testing day of what we are truly made of is coming, and it should not be a surprise to us on that Day. While non-believers will be judged in righteousness, Christians will be judged on their works unto the Lord. Are you ready for such a Day? Paul reminds us of the urgency of being ready for this test on God's calendar.
  3. The Fire Will Reveal All! What is the result when one burns up wood, hay, and straw? Ashes. However, what happens when gold, silver and precious stones are burned up? The dross (the impurities) surface until all that remains is the pure precious metal. It was the valuable metals and precious stones (Rev 21:18-21) that were used to adorn ancient temples. Are not we too the temple of God (1 Cor. 2:12)? The fire is not testing the quantity built rather the quality of what you are made of, and the fire won't lie, but will reveal!
  4. Giving a worthy Gift to Christ. What do you desire to lie down at the feet of your Lord and Savior, ashes or precious metals? We only have this one life to live. This is why Christ Himself commands "But store up for yourselves treasures in heaven…For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also." Will your face be shining in the precious metals you lay at Christ's feet, or will your face be saddened in the ashes of temporal works? I believe many will be saddened knowing that they could have stored up the gifts He desired. Examine what you are made of; remember the Day is coming when the fire will reveal all. Give Him a worthy gift, one that He sees not only your reflection in, but more importantly His reflection!

title.rendered: Fed By Obeying His Will (By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
"But he said to them, "I have food to eat that you know nothing about." "My food," said Jesus, "is to do the will of him who sent me and to finish his work." (John 4:32,34)

Have you ever tried to share something with someone and they just didn't comprehend what you were saying? Jesus seemed to run into that situation often, even though He was a Master communicator. Jesus had just finished having a conversation with the women at the well, when his disciples were approaching with lunch. His disciples "were surprised to find him talking with a woman." It was considered improper for a Rabbi to speak with women in public, let alone one that was sexually immoral. The disciples see the women leave, and see her water bucket that she left as evidence of her presence, and not "just their imaginations." But no one asked, 'What do you want?' or 'Why are you talking with her?' I believe, that although no one asked those questions, those were the questions that they had on their minds.

His disciples have these questions, but didn't dare ask them. Therefore, what do men do when they don't want to speak about what is really on their minds? They eat! Eating doesn't take much brain power, similar to watching TV. They urged Jesus, "Rabbi, eat something." Jesus however knowing their thoughts replies, "I have food to eat that you know nothing about." Now they are thinking that someone came and gave Jesus food. Jesus continues by saying, "My food," said Jesus, "is to do the will of him who sent me and to finish his work." Now they were really thrown off. What was Jesus getting at, because they were talking about food, but Jesus wasn't talking about food, He was talking about FOOD! What was this food?

  1. The fulfillment Jesus just has with ministering to the lost women.
  2. The overall life mission of reconciling the world to the Father through Himself as the bridge.
  3. The sustenance of pleasing His Father by obeying the mission that He gave Jesus to live out.
  4. The very hunger He possessed, they did not yet crave, and that is being salt to make sinners thirsty for the water that the women received.

What was the work Jesus was to finish? Just as drinking from the well would cause the women to thirst again, so too will the disciples hunger again if their food source was from town supermarket. The women needed the living water, and the disciples needed the bread of life, and the desire to seek and save the lost just as Jesus had. When the women was filled with the water of life she began to bring others to Jesus, and that is what Jesus was looking for in His Twelve. "Do you not say, 'Four months more and then the harvest'? I tell you, open your eyes and look at the fields! They are ripe for harvest. 36 Even now the reaper draws his wages, even now he harvests the crop for eternal life, so that the sower and the reaper may be glad together. 37 Thus the saying 'One sows and another reaps' is true. 38 I sent you to reap what you have not worked for. Others have done the hard work, and you have reaped the benefits of their labor." Jesus wanted the eyes of the disciples opened to the fields, NOT to their "food!" Job said, "I have treasured the words of his mouth more than my daily bread." Jesus said told you and me to seek and save the lost. When we obey God in this, we too will eat the food that many do not know of. Are you hungry? Go to the harvest fields of your schools and jobs, and finish the work by the power of the Holy Spirit, and be fed by obeying His will!

title.rendered: Sleeping on the Job

content.rendered:
Good morning friends

Mathew 13:24-30, "…The Kingdom of heaven is likened unto a man which sowed good seeds in his field: but while men slept, his enemy came and sowed tares among the wheat, and went his way"

The bible lets us know about how the Kingdom of God is likened to, and we are told in this case how it's likened unto a man who sowed good seeds in his field. This man did not sow bad seeds but good seeds. The moment we accept Christ, we sow good seeds in the field that He has prepared, our hearts. The word of God is a seed partially because in John 12:24, "tells us that unless the grain of wheat falls into the ground and dies, it abides alone but if it dies, it will be able to bare much fruit". Jesus was the seed that died and we are a result of the seed that died. Once again we see a man who sowed good seeds not in anyone's field but his field. Everything was okay as he natured that seed, dug around it, watered it and watched over it. Good Morning Everybody,

It gives me pleasure once again to share my learning of the word with you all . for today I chose the topice "Attitude of gratitude"

When do we give thanks unto the Lord – how do we give Him thanks – what do we give Him thanks for ???

When someone does something good for us, it maybe even a little thing, we cant just sit there and ignore than fact that he has done this favor or a good deed to us, we would want to express our gratitude to that person, tell him /her how thankful we are. and in turn that person is so happy. Sometimes it makes us so happy but just saying "thank you, I really appreciate your help". When we can do it so easily and naturally without any effort, to people around us, it is even more easier for us to keep letting the Lord know how much we are thankful to Him for every little act He is performing in our lives. And later It would become so difficult for us to just sit and keep receiving everything from Him and not letting Him know how much that meant to us. We develop an attitude of gratitude.

David is a perfect example to us for the way he gave thanks to the Lord for just anything and everything. He would just say "Give thanks to the Lord for He is good and his love endures forever" as in Psalms 118:1 and 107:1, simply giving thanks for His goodness. If we like a person, whenever we get a chance to meet him or her we just let them know how nice they are or how happy we are to meet them, or appreciate them in something or the other, its just a human reflex. Likewise David used to just keep on praising and thanking the Lord for his unfailing and everlasting love, his kindness, his mercy, his grace.

Paul is another person from who teaches us how to be grateful to God in everything. as he says in 1 Thess 5:18 – "Give thanks in all circumstances, for this is God's will for you in Christ Jesus". this answers two of our questions – when do we give thanks and the basic reason why we need to give thanks. So whenever we seek God's will in our lives for anything we should always remember that His will for us is also to give Him thanks in everything . No condition in this world is so bad where there is nothing to give thanks for. Now lets look at some reasons for telling Jesus "Thank You", we shall look into just three reasons out of the many, today.

  1. Thanks for bread: In our every day walk in life we as usual thank the Lord for the food we eat. Jesus himself thanked the Father in heaven before he broke the bread as in 1 Corinth 11:24. We see Paul giving thanks for the bread in Acts 27.35.
  2. Thanks for eternal life through Jesus Christ: This is God's indescribable gift to us which no man can give unto us and that makes us special children of the Most High God. As in 2 Corinth 9:17 we should give thanks unto the Lord for his gratitude.

Thanks for the victory over death: Death is something common man is afraid of, but we know that if we die her eon earth, we get to live with Him in Heaven. 1 Corinth 15: 35 to 58 explains very clearly the Resurrection Body. A very powerful teacher of the word once explained that when a bee stings once, it loses its second sting, so it becomes harmless after the first sting. All it can do is buzz around you and scare you but this time you know that it is not going to harm you. Likewise Jesus took that sting of death for us so it is not going to affect us anymore nor scare us. Death can only buzz around us but it is powerless to hurt us. So we see another reason to thank Him for His victory over death. As in 1 Corinth 15:55 and 56, "Where O death is your victory? where O death is your sting?".

You can find so many reasons to thank the Lord. Its a never ending list. Praise the Lord !!!

Thanks,

Have a wonderful day!

Jemima Elizabeth Benhur

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Vs 6, "The ravens brought him bread in the morning, and bread and meat in the evening; and he drank from the brook, vs. 7, "And it happened after awhile that the brook dried up, because there had been no rain in the land". There are certain jobs, positions, ministries that God allowed us to be in for a while for He fed us, ministered to us, provided for us and the like and we knew for sure that it was God's will to be in that place, but we need to understand that there are times when the brook dries up meaning that which you thought would always be there is gone, the zeal you had for that position dried up, the patience you had for that thing dries up. At this time it's very easy to say it may have not been God's will for me to be there but the truth of the matter is, it was God's will for you to be there but for just for a season. When you are beginning to get comfortable, He will relocate you so as to depend on God even more, change causes us to see God in different dimensions and change also allows us not to limit God in any way. If God provided away for me to be at this brook, I believe that He has already provided another way for He is the way maker.

Guys, the brook can dry up, your spiritual brook can dry up, zeal to serve others can dry up, finances can dry up, and jobs and positions can also dry up for we the believers are nomadic people always on the move climbing from glory to glory. Don't expect to find some of us in the previous brooks for when they dried up, it was time to trust God for the next move.. Don't be trying to revive a brook that dried up for what God has closed can no man open and what God has opened can no man close. Ask the Lord what direction to take, He has a lot of ways of blessing His people.

At the brook he wasn't serving and yet he had enough, at the widow's, he is expected to serve while there is less than enough but the good news is that he is sent to rescue someone else. title.rendered: The Harp Vs. the Javelin (By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
"And it came to pass on the morrow, that the evil spirit from God came upon Saul, and he prophesied in the midst of the house: and David played with his hand, as at other times: and there was a javelin in Saul's hand. And Saul cast the javelin; for he said, I will smite David even to the wall with it. And David avoided out of his presence twice. And Saul was afraid of David, because the LORD was with him, and was departed from Saul." 1 Sam. 18:10-12 It has been said "the pen is mightier than the sword." However, few may know that Edward George Bulwer Lytton (1803-1873), an English novelist, wrote this for the first time in 1839. He wrote, "Beneath the rule of men entirely great, the pen is mightier than the sword." http://humanities.byu.edu/elc/student/idioms/proverbs/the_pen.html. In the natural this doesn't make sense, but there are great spiritual truths to be learned in principal. In the days of David, King Saul's jealousy toward David grew to a place of attempted murder.In the heat of battle I would much rather have a javelin than a harp. What can I do with a harp in battle? Perhaps with my musical ability I could play the harp in such a manner that my lack of talent would cause the enemy to cover their ears and retreat. A harp was a grounded instrument, a stable instrument, while a javelin in a weapon that one can carry around. This reminds me of that character of Saul and David. David was grounded in God, as the presence of God rested upon him. Saul was flighty and unstable; one never knew when Saul would "loose it" and snap. Saul lived by his emotions and his title as king. David lived by his godly character and His anointing to soon become the king. David was patient and obedient, while Saul was hurried and disobedient.

Now David had a harp in his hand while Saul had a javelin in his. With the harp David pleased God, drove evil spirits away from Saul and thus served the king. With the javelin Saul purposed to pin David to death upon the wall. David was growing in popularity as the people said, "Saul hath slain his thousands, and David his ten thousands." Although Saul had the title as king, he feared David greatly because the Lord was with David and had departed from Saul. The Apostle Paul penned the words, "…If God is for us, who can be against us?" God was for David because David was righteous. He had a right standing before God. As a spiritual boxing match, God was in David's corner, just as He was when David killed Goliath. David's behaved very wisely and Saul behaved very fearfully. I imagine that Saul was quit skilled with the Javelin, but when he threw it at David, David dodged the weapon. Although Saul tried to kill David, David NEVER tried to retaliate in any way against Saul. In this day and age many pride themselves on subverting authority when one feels they are in the right. David had the Spirit of God, and therefore was defending by God. David teaches us many things.

  • Use what God gives you, even if it a simple harp.
  • Be stable in God
  • Behave in wisdom not in fear. (fear God not man)
  • Know that if God is for you, who can be against you. (Rom. 8:31)
  • Learn to dodge what the enemy throws your way.
  • Respect your authorities even when they are wrong (this is tough, but necessary for God's people).
  • Submit to authority don't subvert authority (don't throw javelins back!)
  • Submit to God and be guided by His spirit.

Until the nets are filled…

Blessings, Pastor Phil <><

content.rendered:
Good morning1Kings 17:1-7, "And it happened after a while that the brook dried up, because there had been no rain in the land"

It's very easy to talk about God providing but waiting for Him to provide can be very difficult. We know this for sure for the word of God says that in Isaiah 55:8&9, "for my thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways my way, for as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways" says the Lord. When you think that everything is out of control, He is in control for nothing escapes Him. Eccle 3:11, "He has made everything beautiful in His time". We need to understand that it's His time that counts and not my time.

Elijah the prophet in 1Kings 17 has just prophesied to king Ahab that there would be no rain in Israel for a period of three years. If you look at chapter 16 of 1Kings vs. 33, "And Ahab made a wooden image. Ahab did more to provoke the Lord God of Israel to anger than all the kings of Israel who were before him". Ahab was bad news, he had married a wicked woman by the name of Jezebel who turned his heart away from God. Anytime God is getting ready to do something in a land, He will always provide a way for escape for His children. Though the wickedness of Ahab provoked God to shut the heavens from providing rain, everyone in the land of Israel had to be affected by that circumstance regardless of whether they were righteous or not. It's true even today people do things that cause others to suffer and yet they are innocent.

I thank God that there is therefore now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus, (Romans 8:1) for in times of trouble God will hide us under His pavilion in the secret of His tabernacle shall He hide me (Psalm 91) for in the absence of everything that I need daily, He will provide according to His riches in glory by Christ Jesus, (Phil 4:19). Elijah has just prophesied and the prophesy also affects him for he lives in Israel but He is faithful to take God at His word. 1Kings 17:2&3, "Then the word of the Lord came to him, saying, "Get away from here and turn eastward, and hide by the Brook Cherith, which flows into the Jordan. And it will be that you shall drink from the brooks, and I have commanded thee ravens to feed you there". Praise God for His plans and provisions, in as much as there is drought in the land, God has preserved a brook for His chosen man, and on the other hand, He has commanded the ravens to feed him with bread and meat. I would pause here for a sec. I understand something about the brook for it must have been flowing from the river Jordan, but how do you explain the bread, where was the bread and meat coming from? who was baking the bread? and how come the raven could not eat the bread? and to make it even interesting, the raven knew who Elijah was. We will never fully grasp how God works but we sure love when He does the impossible. He is the God who takes less and does much with it. He is the God who does things that leaves you wondering how he did it and it's for us also to understand that our ways are not His ways. How we see things are not how He sees them. When you least expect Him to move that is the time He will move. When you think that there is nothing around He can use, that is the time He will surprise you by taking that little thing and making something great out of it. There could be something around you, at your job, an idea, a seed at home you never thought He could use, but don't be surprised to see the things you despised being used to get you to the next level. to continue

title.rendered: You Got A Job To Do, Be Initiative

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Genesis 39:1-23, "And his master saw that the Lord was with him and that Lord made all he did to prosper in his hand."

One time I was watching TV when one of the divorce courts shows came on. One lady had filed for a divorce because her husband was not supporting the family. She accused him of going places and not being there for her and her children when in the actual sense, he was busy working hard to provide and care for his family. This lady was divorcing him primarily because he wasn't providing. While still talking about what the husband wasn't doing, it was discovered that after she kicked her husband out of the house, she began to date and live with another guy who had no income, actually she was providing for him. All he did was sit, watch TV all day while she worked hard to provide for her family and him. Sounds interesting and scary but things happen out there.

What would you do when what you always dreamed for wasn't coming to pass?, instead of things getting better and better to lead you towards that dream, you got further and further away from it. Joseph is a good example, he had a dream at the age of 17 and his dream was not that one day he will fail but that one day he will be great and that his family and many people would bow to him. Talk to any teenagers today and hear all their dreams and desires of success. You must have had dreams at that age too. Joseph has a good dream but he is naive, boastful and insensitive towards his brothers. There is a lot of character to build before he comes to his dream that he does not even have an idea it will come to pass.

Genesis 39:1, "Now Joseph had been taken down to Egypt. And Potiphar, an office of Pharaoh… brought him from Ishmaelites who had taken him down there". He is brought to Egypt as a slave, bowing to someone else. What happened to the dream to which people were bowing to him? It's not surprising that some people become careless when things are not going as they planned and expected, they begin to misuse what they have, they treat position they have casually, doing a poor job because that is not where they wanted to land, sitting down being lazy but what did Joseph do?, he wasn't where he desired to be but yet he was still faithful, hard working, honest, efficient, effective, responsible and initiative in all he did. vs. 2, "The Lord was with Joseph, and he was successful man; and he was in the house of his master the Egyptian". I would expect that if the Lord was with him, that could have opened a door for complaints, murmuring, bitterness and anger towards the Lord. He would have done all yet he saw this as an opportunity to enlarge his character, Philippians 2:14, "Do all things without complaining and disputing". It's like Joseph saying, "I am not where I desired to be and I don't know whether I will get there but now I have responsibility under my master and I will do it faithfully, do well and make my master proud". I don't believe the Lord told him what to do, he just saw an opportunity to serve and the Lord blessed him for being initiative. Later he was made overseer of the entire house of Potiphar, things are getting better, he is good at what he is doing and the Lord is really blessing the house and then he looses his position because Potiphar's wife who wanted him to sleep with her. Once beaten and thrown in prison, someone would think he would stop being the man of character but even in prison, he served, he was initiative and responsible. This allowed him to have favor with the keeper of prison and once again he was made in charge.

Joseph allowed people to see the Lord inside of him through working hard, being responsible and being a man who was initiative. Whatever he did, the Lord made it prosper and so is with us today. You may not be where you want to be in career, relationship, job wise, position but you can still be all you can for God even where you are. Don't sit and wait for the Lord to bring you to your destiny when He has allowed you to be in a place that will tailor you to your destiny. Initiative is doing good things without being told, do the best you can with all you have and the Lord will bless and prosper you in all you do.

Blessings

Evans

title.rendered: STOP So You Can GO

content.rendered:
"The Spirit told Philip, "Go to that chariot and stay near it." Then Philip ran up to the chariot and heard the man reading Isaiah the prophet. "Do you understand what you are reading?" Philip asked. And he gave orders to stop the chariot. Then both Philip and the eunuch went down into the water and Philip baptized him. When they came up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord suddenly took Philip away, and the eunuch did not see him again, but went on his way rejoicing." (Acts 8:29-30; 38-39)During war time in the military when a platoon is trying to find the enemy and the military leader suddenly places his hand in the air and closes his fight, all his immediately stop. Why because their eyes are on their leader, and one more step could be a land mind and blow off their leg, or end their very life. Even towns and cities know the value of stopping which is why they have placed stop signs and stop lights to better control traffic.

There are times when God wants us to stop and not take another step forward. Perhaps one is reading God's word and a certain truth seems to bring off the page into your spirit and it stops you in your tracks. If you're like most, you stop for a moment because it's like a stop light, and then you envision a green light and you go. However, when God stops you as you are reading His word, it is because there is a truth, a warning, an encouragement, a piece of wisdom, etc… that He has for you now. In our church one member was reading the Scriptures and the words from Genesis, "Who told you that," seemed to leap off the page at them. This in turn caused her to weigh the words others said to them, or perhaps even their own thoughts that came into their mind. Have you said to yourself, "I'm a failure," or were you ever told hurtful words such as "you'll never amount to anything." Who told you that! Did God say that to you? When we are stopped in our tracks as we read God's word, there is a reason and God knows that reason, and failure to stop at that verse, passage, question, word, command will result in a consequence. A soldier failing to stop could be killed, a car failing to stop at a light may crash, a Christian failing to stop will feel the effect and it could be disastrous. Just as the military leader signals stop because he senses grave danger ahead, how much more should we as Christians stop, because when God says "STOP," He sees what is ahead for us, and failing to stop when He says stop will not turn out in our favor.

The Spirit told Philip to go and STOP at the chariot, but never gave the reason to Philip. Philip ran and STOPPED hearing the eunuch reading the Scriptures, and Phillip shared Jesus with him. Imagine if Philip didn't STOP. Who would have explained the passage of Scripture to the eunuch? Then the newly converted eunuch gave orders to stop the chariot. Then both Philip and the eunuch went down into the water and Philip baptized him. However when they came up out of the water the Holy Spirit had translated Philip 30 miles away to another town. This may be difficult to fathom, but if Jesus can be taken from death to life, then Philip can be taken from town to town. Imagine if they had never stopped for the baptism and at specific time the Holy Spirit was going to take Philip away, then who would have baptized the eunuch.

When God tells you to STOP it is for your own good, so that you can GO right! Is there a verse, passage of Scripture, habit, ect…, that God has said STOP? What are you moving for? Today is the day to STOP in your tracks, because the next step may be something that you can't handle without receiving what you need when you are stopped. Even a car stops for gas, can't God's people stop from Him!

title.rendered: Sowing and Reaping – By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
"So they sat down in ranks, in hundreds and in fifties. And when He had taken the five loaves and the two fish, He looked up to heaven, blessed and broke the loaves, and gave them to His disciples to set before them; and the two fish He divided among them all. So they all ate and were filled. And they took up twelve baskets full of fragments and of the fish." (Mark 6:40 – 43)

Sowing and reaping is a farming principal that certainly melds over into a variety of life situations outside farming. The farming practice is that if you sow your seed at the right time, in due season (harvest time) you will reap plentiful crops. The Scriptures show us that times when this principle certainly has been misrepresented in life practice. Recall in Matt. 25 the man that buried his talent and upon his return the master found that the servant had not sown it so that it would grow, and therefore no profit was reaped. He was called a wicked lazy servant and cast out, never to be entrusted with the masters goods. The prodigal son sowed his wild oats and, at some point I imagine, prayed for "crop failure."

The disciples wanted to send the people away to the country and the villages to go buy themselves bread, for they had nothing to eat. Jesus turned to his disciples and said you feed them. The disciples were most likely discouraged as they thought of the impossible amount of money it would take to feed a crowd like this one. The Expositors Bible Commentary tells us "Two hundred denarii represented the pay a common laborer earned in a period of about eight months (cf. Matt 20:2-15, where the usual pay for a day's wage is one denarius). Not even that amount of money would buy enough bread for all to eat (cf. John 6:7: "for each one to have a bite"). Knowing this, makes their feelings make a lot of sense. Then he asked them how much food they had with them, and they replied five loaves of bread and two fish. Perhaps again they were thinking, "Jesus if you take the little bit of food we have and give it to these people you will have done two stupid things, one there is not enough to feed these people, and two we won't have any food to eat then. However, Jesus had his men instruct the crowd to sit down in ranks of hundreds and by fifties. Jesus was beginning to show his men how he would use their lives, help, and resources to be a blessing to others. Jesus took the food they had, blessed it, broke it, and gave them to his disciples.

The result was two fold. First, "they did all eat AND WERE FILLED… and they that did eat…were about five thousand men [not counting women and children]." Second, "and they [the disciples] took up TWELVE baskets full of fragments, and of fishes."

When we sow our resources into the Kingdom of God, hence give the Lord what is really rightfully His everything we are caretakers of, he can bless it, break it and feed multitudes with it. He can do miracles with what you sow into the Kingdom. The disciples, although not knowing the outcome, and perhaps being nervous about their own hunger being in jeopardy, obeyed Christ and were blessed. Their sowing of food, resulted in everyone being feed to their hearts content, and there were TWELVE baskets left over. Were there not twelve disciples? You see when you sow into His Kingdom with the little you have, He will provide for your needs.

title.rendered: When He Calls Me, Part 5

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Chapter 2:1, "Then Jonah prayed to the Lord His God from the fish's belly. And he said:, "I cried by reason of mine affliction unto the Lord and he heard me; out of the belly of hell cried I, and thou heardest my voice". Amen, out of the belly of the fish cried I to the Lord. Out of the mess I got myself into cried I unto the Lord and He heard me and answered me. God had every right to reject Jonah's prayers but His love is an everlasting love and if we call on Him, He will answer us. Being in the belly of the fish reminded him that God was always there with him and that is why he could call. That was a place of humility where he would say, "Lord is not about me but about you", WHEN YOU CALL ME, I WILL ANSWER; WHEN YOU LEAD ME I WILL FOLLOW; WHEN YOU SEND ME I WILL GO; WHEN YOU NEED ME, I WILL BE AVAILABLE AND WHEN YOU FIND ME, I WILL BE DOING SOMETHING FOR YOU. Read it for yourself and you will see how he was vomited and he takes the assignment with dignity and humility.

So lets find out why Jonah decided to run from the presence of God. Being that Nineveh was a wicked city, God had passed a judgment that the city would be destroyed in 40 days. Jonah's mission was to come and preach this message in this city. The reason why he did not want to go to the city was not because he feared how the message was terrible or whether people would kill him because of that but because he knew that the moment he preached the message, many were going to repent and be saved and God would show mercy unto them even though He promised to destroy the city. This was his problem and that is God giving grace to a perverted city but after realizing that he also needed grace, mercy and pardon when he messed up, the people of Nineveh also needed such a chance to have grace, mercy and pardon when they also messed upon and turned away from God.

Do we have to hit rock bottom to cry out to God? Do we call on Him when things are bearable? do we desire to see some of our friends and family members come to a place of grace, mercy and pardon just as we did receive it, or would we care less as long as we are okay. WHEN HE CALLS ME, I WILL ANSWER TO THAT CALL.

If I had more time, I would dig through this book even more but let's conclude it this morning by knowing that God is love, full of mercy and compassion, His presence is everywhere, He cares about sinners and that is the reason He is calling His people that He may send them and that He is a God of second chances.
