title.rendered: Communicating the Kingdom (Part 3) – a revision originally by Mark Rutland

content.rendered:
Good Morning,Please enjoy part 3 of the series, Commmunicating the Kingdom.

"After his suffering, he showed himself to these men and gave many convincing proofs that he was alive. He appeared to them over a period of forty days and spoke about the kingdom of God." Acts 1:3

As they approached Jerusalem and came to Bethpage on the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two disciples, 2 saying to them, "Go to the village ahead of you, and at once you will find a donkey tied there, with her colt by her. Untie them and bring them to me. Matt 21:1-2

Now they come to Jerusalem, Jesus descends from the Mt. Of Olives toward the Eastern Gate, the people are joyous in their expression. And their language to His presence is very intriguing. They express the great contemporary hope for the coming of Messiah, Kingship. And they are shouting "Hosanna to the King that comes in the name of the Lord!" Hosanna doesn't mean Hallelujah, Hosanna means save us now. They were saying King save us now! Were they saying save us from our sins? NO, not at this point, they wanted Him to save them from the Romans

The Romans are just across the Kidron Valley watching out of the Towers of the Antonio Fortress. That's the reason that the Pharisees are telling Jesus Master, make the people be quiet, they are going to get us all killed. The Romans are going to rush out of that fortress and kill us all. There is only one King, and his name is Caesar.

This whole issue explodes into the lives of the disciples, especially the Apostles that are saying, "This is it, this is the time." And they are feeling Jesus giving the idea that He has establish not only political leadership, but religious leadership. What is His first act? Jesus goes into the Temple and drives the money changers out, as if to say this also is mine. He says this "My house and it will be a house of prayer." He claims authority, and that authority is even yielded to. Why didn't they just throw Jesus out, there were more of them, then there was of Him. Maybe they in part feared the people. Maybe because they thought, "don't mess with this guy, He acts like He owns the place."

The disciples meanwhile are triumphant in their thoughts. They are thinking this is it, "He is going to establish His kingdom." We know this is what they were thinking, because remember Zebede's wife, mother of James and John, came to Jesus and said, "When you come into your kingdom, let my sons sit on either side of you" (Mt. 20:20-21). Everyone wants Jesus to have the big chair, one big throne, nobody wants that. But she's thinking there are going to be six little chairs on either side of him, why not claim those. And the other Apostles are furious at James and John's mother, why, because she infringed upon divine authority? No because she beat them to the punch. They want those chairs, and are jockeying for position. Did they not ask at one point, "Who is the greatest in the Kingdom of heaven?" (Mt. 18:1) As kingdom authority is about to come, they are thinking that He is going to come like an Arnold Swartnegger, and blow the mean old Romans out of the water. Maybe He'll nail Pilate to the walls of Jerusalem, as he had the previous year nailed 600 Jews to the walls of Jerusalem.

What does Jesus do instead? He retires to a place of pray, allows He to be arrested, He's crucified, dead, buried, and as the stone is rolled across the grave, and entombed with Him are all their hopes of Messianic kingdom. He is going to appear to an ex-hooker (Mary Magdalene) in a cemetery? I don't think so. I wouldn't have done that. content.rendered:
Good morning,Please enjoy part two of Communicating the Kingdom

"After his suffering, he showed himself to these men and gave many convincing proofs that he was alive. He appeared to them over a period of forty days and spoke about the kingdom of God." Acts 1:3

As a reminder, this is the passage of Scripture occurs between the resurrection and the ascension, in the 40-day span of time that Jesus has been raised from the dead, but not yet ascended to the right hand of the Father.

The disciples that Jesus was speaking to were not Pharisees (forget negative implication of that word). They were not students of the law, Bible scholars, or theologian level minded people. These were ordinary, working class people, blue collared fisherman with calluses on their hands, and calluses on their brains. And into their lives SUDDENLY EXPLODES THE LONG AWAITED HOPE OF ISRAEL. Jesus chooses in our eyes, a highly unlikely group to make into His team that would turn the world upside down for Him.

Isn't it comforting that "God chooses the foolish things of this world, to confound the wise?" As the statement goes, "Lord if You can use anyone Lord, You can use me". These people were not acting out of script. Sometimes, at least at a subconscious level, I think we believe that these men were acting out of script. Peter is washing his nets by the Sea of Galilee, sees Jesus walking up the beach and says, oh Matt chap. 6. These men are experiencing this all for the very first time. They don't have the benefit of 2,000 years of Bible teaching as we do. We are blessed on one hand to be able to see through hindsight, but they couldn't. And they spend the next 3 years asking one fundamental question, "Who is this guy?"

Jesus projects the question in Matt 16:13 that He knows they are wondering, as He states, WHO DO MEN say that I the Son of man am? They respond by sharing the majority view, the people's opinion. Some say you are John the Baptist: some, Elijah, (YOU'RE NOT ELIJIAH ARE YOU); others, Jeremiah, or one of the prophets. They don't know what to think. Then Jesus puts the bulls eye right on them, and fires the question, "BUT WHO DO YOU say that I am?" Now He's seeing if the men who had been walking with Him all along, have a clue about His identity.

And what happens, but good old Simone Peter opened his mouth as usual. Peter was one who was known for speaking up when he should shut up; stand up when he should sit down, etc… He says, I know who you are; "You're the Christ, the Son of the living God. BINGO, Peter got it right finally. But, I can imagine everyone freezing, expecting Jesus to smite Peter in the mouth, which was the ancient symbol for blasphemy. Does Jesus smite him, indeed not? He says you're right; the Father has given you a faith revelation. Well there it is the cats out of the bag, Jesus is known as Messiah, Son of God.

Application: How did you receive the revelation that He is the Messiah? With the Passion of Christ being a huge topic, why not ask people as a lead in witnessing question, who do you think Jesus Christ is, and why? If you know Christ, you'll know where to take it from there.

Blessings,

Pastor Phil <><

title.rendered: Communicating the Kingdom –  a revision originally by Mark Rutland

content.rendered:
Good Morning,

With Resurrection Sunday upcoming, I thought to share this series with you from 2004. Today's focus is Acts 1.

"After his suffering, he showed himself to these men and gave many convincing proofs that he was alive. He appeared to them over a period of forty days and spoke about the kingdom of God (Acts 1:3)."

This is the passage of Scripture occurs between the resurrection and the ascension, in the 40-day span of time that Jesus has been raised from the dead, but not yet ascended to the right hand of the Father.

For 40 days this resurrected Christ teaches them basically on one topic: The Kingdom of God. He could have spoken any topic, but why did He choose to speak only on this one topic? Because a King always speaks about His Kingdom – AMEN! And so Jesus really is the first cross-cultural missionary, leaving his home in glory, taking the form of man, and attempting to explain heavenly transcendent truth

Acts 1:6 "So when they met together, they asked him, "Lord, are you at this time going to restore the kingdom to Israel?'"

Can you see that you can draw a line between their conclusion/question and His 40 days of ministry? He has been teaching them about the Kingdom. And their thinking "this is it, this is the time that you are going to restore the kingdom, isn't it?"

AC 1:7 He said to them: "It is not for you to know the times or dates the Father has set by his own authority. 8 But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit comes on you; and you will be my witnesses in Jerusalem, and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the ends of the earth."

Here is Jesus' response focuses on two components, time and power. The disciples wanted King Jesus to be like the Hulk, or the Terminator and crush the Romans under His thumb, just as the Israelites had been under the thumb of the Romans, and they thought he would do it with an iron scepter.

I can't imagine that there has ever been a group of people whose emotions have endured a more dread itineration that the Apostles. It is hard for us to empathize what they dealing with. However, at least we can realize that these were not people that were in some way intellectually, emotionally, relationally, or even spiritually prepared for the events which ERRPUTED into their lives. What did they hear about Jesus, He's king, He's not, He's alive, He's dead, He's alive again, He loves me, He loves me not, they said I can't do this anymore. Jesus is saying to these guys, "OK guys you think this whole thing is about power, it's not about power, it's about POWER!

Do you see this whole conversation, is an issue of miscommunication? They're thinking KINGDOM; the Davidic dynasty reestablished, with it's geopolitical, socioeconomic, and religious center at Jerusalem. Jesus in the throne and they ruling and reigning with Him 1,000 yrs. What did Isa. Say, "you shall you the nations with a rod of iron," they ruled us with a rod of iron, THAT SOUNDS GOOD TO ME, I CAN"T WAIT! And isn't that so like us, we all want power, but our means of getting it is usually through manipulation, deception, or intimidation. The power the disciples were thinking of, and the power Jesus was promising, were from two totally different perspectives, and realms. More will follow at another time.

Application: Do you have the power that Jesus spoke of in your life?

Blessings,

title.rendered: Scars Are Not Wounds, be Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Romans 8:1, "There is therefore now no condemnation to those who are in Christ Jesus, who do not walk according to the flesh, but according to the Spirit"

Resurrection Sunday is a Sunday that depicts the victory of Jesus over death when He rose from the dead. There had to be a death experience before there was resurrection victory. Death could not hold or contain Him, sin tried but He conquered the day that death was crucified. 1 Corinthians 15:55, "O Death, where is your sting? O Hades, where is your victory?" O Death, where is your victory? O Death, where is your sting?. Jesus came back to life, complete and whole, the original Jesus but there was something that He came back with and that is the scars. The marks of nails on His hands and feet and the mark of where they pierced Him on His side. I have often wondered why those marks did not disappear at His resurrection. I believe they would serve as a reminder to us of what He had to go through for us to be saved, also proof to those who had a problem believing like Thomas. He was wounded for our transgressions according to Isaiah 53:5 yet in His coming back to life He did not have wounds but scars.

Scars ought to be reminders but many treat them as wounds. They go about poking the scars bringing back the wounds that were already healed. Are you living a condemned life over what God had forgiven you off and given you freedom to live for Him? The scars which is your history is not a wound but a reminder of where He called you from. Whenever I remember where He called me from, I get so humbled to the fact that He saw my need and picked me up from the miry clay when no one else could. I don't use the reminders to condemn myself, I use the reminders to thank Him for what He did for me on the cross. I'm glad that even though He saved me, He did not take away my scars (history) and because of that, this scripture comes alive Romans 8:1, "There is therefore now no condemnation to those who are in Christ Jesus,…". Those who are in Christ have their sins washed way by the blood of the Lamb. The blood of the Lamb is the only blood that could screen the sin when nothing else could. The blood of the Lamb is the only blood that not only took care of what I did, it also took care of what almost did and what I could have ever done. The blood handled many worse things we could have done had He not come soon enough. It took care of the past, present and future. Water is suppose to take care of what is dirty and nothing more, it will not wash away any dirt that is not there, the blood goes beyond. Because we are washed by the blood, yes we might still have scars seen but we will not feel condemned anymore as they are not wounds. Psalm 103:12, "As far as the east is from the west, So far has He removed our transgressions from us". You might remind the Lord of your past sin but He chooses to remember it no more because He forgave you of it.

Lord if You chose to leave the scars on Your body when You came back to life, Help me live with the scars of where you called me from. No more will I treat them as wounds as I am not condemned anymore now that I live for You.

Be blessed Ev

title.rendered: May Not See What I See, by Evans

content.rendered:
Acts 7:54-60, "Look! I see the heavens opened and the Son of Man standing at the right hand of God!"Every day presents it's self in different patterns. Each day is unique and there will be no other day ike today. As every day appears unique, at times what we deal with and encounter can appear unique. Moving and operating in cycles and circles does bring a change. What I see may not be what you see; what I deal with may not be what you deal with but we are all seeing things differently and deal with things differently. What is the truth we all need to see?.

Stephen was known as a man of faith and full of the Holy Spirit. There was such a massive power invested in him and with that he did great wonders and signs among the people. Very few people liked what he did as most of them conspired to kill him. Those who conspired to kill him first thought of disputing him, Acts 6:8, says, "And they were not able to resist the wisdom and the Spirit by which he spoke". According to 1Peter 3:15, he was ready, which says "But sanctify the Lord God in your hearts; and be ready to give an answer to every man that asks you a reason for the hope that is in you with meekness and fear". Stephen knew who his God was, what had been invested in him and he was not afraid to defend his faith. He had seen what many had not seen and therefore standing out there, he was able to give them a glimpse of what standing for the truth was all about. There are and will be people who will try and challenge your faith in Christ by trying to ask questions, what kind of stand will you take? Romans 1:16, "For I am not a shamed of the gospel of Christ: for it's the power of God unto salvation to everyone who believes…". They lied on him but he stood firm and defended his faith which later led his death. Having encounterd with Christ, they that saw him did not see an ordinary man, Acts 6:15, "And all who sat in the council, looking steadfastly at him, saw his face as the face of an angel". What an awesome opportunity for the people to see him as a man who has encountered with the Lord. He has faith, the Holy Spirit, wisdom, boldness and a shinning face all that come from above. Do people see all these when they encounter with you? Stephen's continuous connection gave him a chance to tap from the heavenly sources that in turn may be revealed to the people.

He takes the time to take the people back to history from the time of Abraham and he covers everything even how the people killed all those who brought the good news. The more the people heard what he had to say, the more they wanted to tear him apart. Acts 7:55, "But he, being full of the Holy Spirit, gazed into heaven and saw the glory go God, and Jesus standing at the right hand of God, vs. 56, "Look! I see the heavens opened and the Son of Man standing at the right hand of God!". Glory be to God, when you know your reason is all about, though you may share with people the truth, many will not see what you see. Stephen is not frustrated because these people are not seeing what he is seeing, they have already seen his shinning face, he is giving them a chance to see where he is getting strength from. Do not be frustrated because people are not seeing what you are seeing, even Elisha had a servant who began to panic because those who were about attack them. Meanwhile Elisha remained calmed for he had seen what his servant had not seen. Instead of him being frustrated with his servant, he prayed to God to open the eyes of his servant to see what he was seeing. I'm working on this part for there are times I would like people especially the unsaved to see what I am seeing and it's tough and can be frustrating, my prayer is that God will open their eyes to see what I see, Jesus sitting on the throne ruling forever and ever.

Acts 7:58, "And they cast him out of the city and stoned him. vs. 59, "And they stoned Stephen as he was calling on God saying, "Lord Jesus receive my Spirit". With His eyes gazing into heaven though he was being stoned, he remained calm and called on God. You can be stoned with words, be ridiculed, be put down and these things can be hurting but as Stephen, look to heaven. Acts 7:60, "Then he knelt down and cried out with a loud voice, "Lord, do not charge them with this sin". And when he had said this, he fell as a sleep". Because what he had seen that people did not see, he couldn't blame them for their actions all he prayed about was forgiveness. Jesus did the same hanging on the cross, those who crucified him did not know what they were doing. If they understood who Jesus was and is, they would have thought twice. Forgive those who stone you with their words, those who talk ill about your faith, those who reject the truth for they haven't seen the light. Remember that they may not see what you see but what they see in you will not be denied. Saul (Paul) was present at the stoning of Stephen, actually he was carrying all the garments of those who stoned Stephen. It's not recorded but I believe that Stephen's last moments must have impacted him in away. A man of God not afraid to be stoned for the sake of Christ. Where he was going could not be compared to where he had come from and there was no reason to hold anything inside. Father forgive them for they know not what they are doing!. Keep seeing what many haven't seen yet!

title.rendered: Roll Away the Reproach of Egypt (By David Jackson)

content.rendered:
Focus: Joshua 5:1-9

Joshua is the leader of a new generation of believers. These believers were not part of the generation of Moses and were not parties to the mighty acts of God in that day. Among all that God had done, nothing was so spectacular as the bondage and absolute deliverance of the Israelis from Egypt. Egypt was the lone world sovereign state. The pharaoh of Egypt exercised unlimited prerogatives and wielded unprecedented power. The scope of the pharaoh’s realm was so vast that it bordered omnipotence. The will of the pharaoh was the law and disloyalty and disobedience guaranteed capital punishment by snakes and alligators. The Israelis were initially given refugee asylum in Egypt and then were turned into political prisoners and forbidden to continue to enjoy and benefit from Egypt’s hospitality. Israeli status grew from guests to hostages to captives to slaves to outcasts. No one can fully understand the damage that the Egyptian experience had on the Israeli psyche. The pharaoh showed the rest of the world exactly what he had in mind for every civilization that resisted him through his Israeli demonstration. The pharaoh stripped the Israelis of anything and everything that gave them significance and meaning. Historians tell us that the pharaoh did not permit the Israelis to cook and eat their customary foods, speak their language, wear their clothes, dance, play their music, etc. Some historians tell us that the Israelis were forced to change their customs and stories concerning Adam, Noah, Job, and the other patriarchs to reflect Egyptian sensitivities. Every reference to God was changed to speak of Ra- the Light and the pharaoh, who was understood to be Ra’s living begotten son. Imagine if somebody today told you to re-learn all of the stories about the early patriarchs but all the chief figures and heroes are Egyptian and all the bad characters were Israeli. The pharaoh effectively saw to it that no one wanted to be of, or in any way linked to, Israel. God eventually purposed to end the abuse and cause another ending for the people of covenant. God superintended every part of their drama, which culminated in the awesome and dreadful display at the Red Sea. Many read the story without appreciating the full import of the meaning. The Red Sea wonder was not directed at just Egypt. Every world leader heard how the Israeli God struck down the divine pharaoh and fame of the incident permanently haunted other leaders with pharaoh-like proclivities. In this scene, the descendants of this grand heritage have a Jordan encounter that rivaled the Red Sea wonder and when the news of it reached the leaders of other nations, the leaders immediately lost the pride and arrogance that fuels the spirit of competition that would contest with Israel. With Israel effectively safe from attack, God tells Joshua to cause the new generation that passed over through the waters to ratify the patriarchal covenant by submitting to circumcision. The new breeds acquiesce. God tells Joshua that on that very day that God removed the reproach of Egypt from them. What is the reproach of Egypt? A reproach is something shameful, scandalous, painful, and ugly. It is something typical of time in prison, slavery, captivity, or bondage. It is something that you don’t want people to know and something you wish you could forget. This reproach can be public, private, and personal. It could be something you picked up on the way or it could be something you have been dealing with all along. What is very clear is that it required God to remove it and He did not remove it until the people responded to His initiative. When the people responded to God, He removed everything shameful about being in and coming from Egypt. God first took them out of Egypt- then He took Egypt out of them. To the Israelis, this represented a new beginning. This renewal and recommitment was essential to Israeli recovery. Much more can be said on this. What most people miss is that part of the Egyptian experience was the mighty deliverance- and it was this that God used to keep Israel’s enemies at bay.

I have been experiencing a spiritual renewal. As God has been soundly demonstrating His faithfulness and sovereignty- He has been disciplining me. The discipline resulted because I was betraying my times of renewal thru several shameful and scandalous habits that cause me to sin. Some I’ve recently picked up and others I’ve been dealing with all along. I could not understand the cycle and I did not know how to break it. As I began to ask God for help- I was reading this story in my devotional study. I realized that I needed God to remove the reproach of Egypt from me. He mercifully took the scandal out of my story. I had to acknowledge that all of my habits (cursing, lust, sleeping around, deceitfulness, etc.) were symbols of bondage and inconsistent with my new walk with God. When I honestly began to address these issues and when I stopped trying to keep others from discovering and detecting these things about me, I saw the reproach roll away. I tell you I’ve never been or felt freer and safer than this. None of my enemies have attacked me at my weaknesses because of what God has done in me in their midst. God can give you renewal. When He does, re-commit your life to Him, and let Him remove the reproach of Egypt from you. Let Him use your experiences to silence your enemies.

Then, try letting what happened in Egypt- stay in Egypt.

title.rendered: Faithfulness Keeps You Safe, by Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,Proverbs 3:3, “Let love and faithfulness never leave you; bind them around your neck, write them on the tablet of your heart”

In looking at different passages in the bible, you find that “LOVE” and “FAITHFULNESS” are joined by the word “and”. “KINDNESS” and “FAITHFULNESS” also appears many times in the bible, these words work together just as we looked at the word “SERVE” and “LOVE”. In a relationship, there can be no faithfulness without love and love cannot continue to flourish without faithfulness. They depend on each other, without one, the other would be dead. Psalm 85:10, “Love and faithfulness meet together..” They are patterned and woven together into each other. They have kissed and bonded to become one.

I would not waste time talking about “love” because if we can master “faithfulness”, we would have mastered “love”. Let’s take the word “FAITHFULNESS” and break it into two parts, “FAITH” and “FULLNESS”. The bible defines faith “as the assurance (the confirmation) of the things [we] hope for, being the proof of things [we] do not see and the conviction of their reality [faith perceiving as real fact what is not revealed to the senses (Hebrews 11:1 AMP). In a relationship, it’s taking what you see as falling and failing and believing that it’s not always bound to be the same forever therefore laboring to keep it alive and better. You don’t expect to give up on it when the going gets tough, you keep seeing something good far beyond the natural and reality. The other aspect of faith is “LOYALTY”, a choice made by an individual to keep a promise (a vow) he or she made. “FULLNESS” is to complete, to give it maximum attention it needs. Give faith a 100% with no doubt of mind and I would term that “FAITHFULNESS”.

One of the things killing marriages today is lack of faithfulness. Faithfulness is the cornerstone of a relationship. If I was to ask couples today what they would consider the most important thing in their marriage, I bet they would tell me “FAITHFULNESS”. Why not love, kindness, respect, support etc as first? It’s because all these are centered around the word “FAITHFULNESS”. Faithfulness involves loving your partner in ways that meet his or her needs. You will love because you are faithful, you will support because you are faithful and you will be kind because you are faithful. Faithfulness implies duty. Faithfulness begins as a choice, the reason Proverbs 3:3, tells us not to “Let love and faithfulness never leave you; bind them around your neck, write them on the tablet of your heart”. It’s the essence of a good Godly blessed marriage (relationship). We can choose to let it leave us by our words and actions. A husband or wife can feel safe knowing their spouse is faithful. Proverbs 20:28 “Love and faithfulness keep a king (queen) safe; through love his (her) throne is made secure”. Husbands are kings of their home (throne) and wives are the queens of their home (throne), their aim is to love and be faithful to each other to keep their kingdom safe and secure. If the kingdom is not safe and secure, expect intruders which leads to unfaithfulness. How many have fell on that trap because their kingdoms were not secured by love and faithfulness? Faithfulness (trustworthy) is very fragile, once broken it’s hard to mend it. The best ways you demonstrate your faithfulness today will build bridges of trust for a life time. Being trustworthy is keeping your word. Don’t let love and faithfulness leave you if you want you marriage (relationship) to grow and flourish. Write it on the table of your heart and remind yourself everyday to keep them.

Blessings
Evans

title.rendered: What makes you burn? By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
“And their eyes were opened, and they knew him; and he vanished out of their sight. And they said one to another, ‘Did not our heart burn within us, while he talked with us by the way, and while he opened to us the scriptures (Luke 24:31 – 32)?'”What makes you burn inside and really come alive? What is that sporting event that you shout for your team? I can reference all the Yankee fans here in NYC that screams when the Yankees play and beat their rivals the Boston Red Sox, even though it didn’t happen this year. Would you come alive if you got that raise at work, or as lawyer won that case or perhaps you were a salesperson and made a big sale? Hiking, swimming, hobbies, computers, dating someone, etc… are some various things that bring life to people. Perhaps the thing that make you burn with enthusiasm and life was not on the list, but you know what that thing is that makes your heart race. In this passage the thing that made hearts burn, and really come alive was the words that Jesus spoke.

This is the passage of Scripture occurs between the resurrection and the ascension, in the 40-day span of time that Jesus has been raised from the dead, but not yet ascended to the right hand of the Father. The women go to visit the tomb that Jesus had been placed in and they find it vacant. They run and tell the disciples and Peter’s feet couldn’t move fast enough to get to the tomb and discover the truth of the women’s news. And they made their way back to where the rest of the disciples and were reminiscing along the way as to their hearts burning while Jesus talked with them by the way (on the road) and when He opened the Scriptures to them. These had a zeal for the very words of Christ. I asked what makes you come alive; now let me ask you, do the Scriptures make you come alive? Is there a burn in your heart as God speaks to you through them, as you discover something new in that passage you’ve read many times before, and if not why not? The early Christians are not really so different from us. At one time it was tax collecting for Matthew, bringing in the big catch for the fisherman, and healing that last patient for Luke, that made these men burn with life. But now, I believe that those temporal things were superceded by the life of God’s word, as there hearts burned at one time for the temporal, now they burned for the spiritual. Jesus said, “My meat is to do the will of him that sent me, and to finish his work,” Because it was Jesus’ sustenance. Where is God’s will found, but in His word. Christian where is your burning heart for God’s Word? If reading these devotions, and Sunday morning church, or mid-week Bible study is all your time in God’s word, then it’s obvious that you’re not reading for yourself, only being spoon fed by others. I believe it was Charles Spurgeon who said, “Some of you have so much dust on your Bible that you could write the word damnation with your finger.”

Think about it, the hearts of the disciples burned for His word so much that we have four gospels to tell of the things they had seen and heard as reliable eyewitnesses of Jesus.

Click on and check the Barna site which shows statistics on Bible reading among Christians.

Why is there testimony not the testimony of believers today? I too get excited about some temporal things, but it does not compare with my excitement over spiritual things. Think of Jeremiah who said “I will not make mention of him, nor speak any more in his name. But his word was in mine heart as a burning fire shut up in my bones, and I was weary with forbearing, and I could not stay.” He tried to keep from preaching God’s word but like trying to throw gasoline on a forest fire, the flames in his heart blazed out and he had to preach what was in him, because he couldn’t put a lid on it! God was the consuming fire with Moses on Mt. Sinai, “For our God is a consuming fire and a jealous God Wherefore we receiving a kingdom which cannot be moved, let us have grace, whereby we may serve God acceptably with reverence and godly fear: (see Duet 4:24, Heb 12:28-29).”

Application: Are you consumed? Does your heart burn like Jeremiah, like the early church? Is your Bible your daily bread that you are enthused about? If so keep it up, if not I challenge you to read at least 15 min a day, record what God is saying to you, and obey what you read.

title.rendered: A Deck of Cards in the Bible

content.rendered:
The young soldier knew it was Sunday, the holiest day of the week. As he was sitting there, he got out an old deck of cards and laid them out across his bunk.

Just then an army sergeant came in and said, “Why aren’t you with the rest of the platoon?”

The soldier replied, “I thought I would stay behind and spend some time with the Lord.”

The sergeant said, “Looks to me like you’re going to play cards.”

The soldier said, “No, sir. You see, since we are not allowed to have Bibles or other spiritual books in this country, I’ve decided to talk to the Lord by studying this deck of cards.”

The sergeant asked in disbelief, “How will you do that?”

“You see the Ace, Sergeant? It reminds me that there is only one God.

The Two represents the two parts of the Bible, Old and New Testaments. !

The Three represents

the Father, Son, and the Holy Ghost.

The Four stands for the Four Gospels: Matthew, Mark, Luke and John.

The Five is for the five virgins there were ten but only five of them were glorified.

The Six is for the six days it took God to create the Heavens and Earth.

The Seven is for the day God rested after making His Creation.

The Eight is for the family of Noah and his wife, their three sons and their wives – the eight people God spared from the flood that destroyed the Earth.

The Nine is for the lepers that Jesus cleansed of leprosy. He cleansed ten, but nine never thanked Him.

The Ten represents the Ten Commandments that God handed down to Moses on tablets made of stone.

The Jack is a reminder of Satan, one of God’s first angels, but he got kicked out of heaven for his sly and wicked ways and is now the joker of eternal hell.

The Queen stands for the Virgin Mary.

The King stands for Jesus, for he is the King of all kings. When I count the dots on all the cards, I come up with 365 total, one for every day of the year.

There are a total of 52 cards in a deck; each is a week – 52 weeks in a year.

The four suits represent the four seasons: Spring, Summer, Fall and Winter.

Each suit has thirteen cards – there are exactly thirteen weeks in a quarter.

So when I want to talk to God and thank Him, I just pull out this old deck of cards and they remind me of all that I have to be thankful for.”

The sergeant just stood there. After a minute, with tears in his eyes and pain in his heart, he said, “Soldier, can I borrow that deck of cards?”
